headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to the Philip Morris International Fourth Quarter 2015 Year End Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is scheduled to last about 1 hour, including remarks by Philip Morris International management and the question-and-answer session
componenttext: Good day, and welcome to the Philip Morris International Fourth Quarter 2015 Year End Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is scheduled to last about 1 hour, including remarks by Philip Morris International management and the question-and-answer session. [Operator Instructions] I will now turn the call over to Mr. Nick Rolli, Vice President of Investor Relations and Financial Communications. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome, and thank you for joining us. Earlier today, we issued a press release containing detailed information on our 2015 fourth quarter and full year results. You may access the release on our website at www.pmi.com.Or the PMI Investor Relations app.
componenttext:
Welcome, and thank you for joining us. Earlier today, we issued a press release containing detailed information on our 2015 fourth quarter and full year results. You may access the release on our website at www.pmi.com.
Or the PMI Investor Relations app. During our call today, we'll be talking about results for the fourth quarter and full year 2015 and comparing them to the same period in 2014, unless otherwise stated.
A glossary of terms, adjustments and other calculations as well as reconciliations to U.S. GAAP measures are at the end of today's webcast slides, which are posted on our website.
Reduced-Risk Products, or RRPs, is the term we used to refer the products with the potential to reduce individual risk and population harm in comparison to smoking cigarettes.
Today's remarks contain forward-looking statements and projections of future results. I direct your attention to the forward-looking and cautionary statements disclosure in today's presentation and press release for a review of the various factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from projections or forward-looking statements.
It's now my pleasure to introduce André Calantzopoulos, our Chief Executive Officer; Jacek Olczak, our Chief Financial Officer, who will join André for the question-and-answer period. André?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Nick, and welcome, ladies and gentlemen. 2015 was an excellent year for PMI. Moderating declines in cigarette industry volume, notably in the EU region, coupled with market share gains, enabled us to record a full year organic cigarette shipmen
componenttext:
Thank you, Nick, and welcome, ladies and gentlemen. 2015 was an excellent year for PMI. Moderating declines in cigarette industry volume, notably in the EU region, coupled with market share gains, enabled us to record a full year organic cigarette shipment volume decline of only 1%, our best performance since 2012. A particular note were the performances of Marlboro and L&M which grew cigarette volume by 0.9% and 3.9% respectively.
Strong pricing across all regions combined with substantially lower unfavorable volume mix compared to recent years resulted in net revenue and adjusted OCI growth excluding currency and acquisitions of 5.8% and 6.6%, respectively.
Despite significant incremental investments behind both and our cigarette brand portfolio are now tonight and disclosed in today's press release. Our adjusted OCI margin increased by 0.3 percentage points to 42.6%, excluding currency and acquisitions. The increase was driven by the EEMA and Latin America and Canada regions. 
Our adjusted diluted EPS, excluding currency, grew by a very strong 12%, at the high end of the rate guidance range that we reaffirmed last November. The strengthening of the U.S. dollar against virtually all of our key operating currencies was an unprecedented headwind for our business in 2015 and resulted in a full year adverse currency impact of $1.20 on our adjusted diluted EPS. 
In our fourth quarter, our organic cigarette volume declined by 2.4% due to lower cigarette industry volumes and lower market share, notably in the Asia region. Our cigarette volume was impacted by a one-time distributor inventory adjustment in Russia related to supply chain optimization. 
Excluding this adjustment, our quarterly volume decline was in line with out of the full year. Net revenues increased by 4%, excluding currency, with favorable pricing across all regions, more than offsetting unfavorable volume mix, mainly the EEMA, Latin America and Canada regions. As previously communicated, our incremental investments in 2015 were concentrated in the fourth quarter. This resulted in currency-neutral adjusted OCI and adjusted diluted EPS declines in the quarter.
Our full year 2015 results confirmed that our business fundamentals are strong and the incremental investments that we made throughout the year and in the fourth quarter, in particular, should further reinforce our momentum in 2016. 
Our reported diluted EPS guidance for 2016 at prevailing exchange rates is a range of $4.25 to $4.35 versus $4.42 in 2015 and includes an unfavorable currency impact of approximately $0.60. This guidance represent the growth rate, excluding currency, of approximately 10% to 12% compared to an adjusted diluted EPS of $4.42 in 2015.
This reflects a currency-neutral adjusted OCI growth rate above our mid- to long-term algorithm. Importantly, this guidance does not include any share repurchases. We revisit the potential for repurchases as the year unfold depending on the currency environment. The $0.60 of unfavorable currency impact are prevailing exchange rate included in our 2016 guidance is driven primarily by the Argentine peso, Indonesian rupee, Japanese yen and Russian ruble. This 4 currencies account for around 60% of the total impact. With currently hedged approximately 72% of our 2016 forecast sales to Japan, which are prevailing exchange rates, translates to an effective rate of JPY 118 to the U.S. versus JPY 110 in 2015. 
Pricing was the key driver of our full year 2015 financial performance. We recorded a total pricing impairments of $2.1 billion supported by strong contributions from all 4 regions. As a reminder, this variance includes an exceptional gain in Korea related to inventories built ahead of the January 2015 excise tax increase, which will not recur in 2016. 
This year, we anticipate the pricing variance of around 6% of our 2015 net revenues. Our performance in 2015 was underpinned by the improving cigarette industry volume trend and continued market share momentum. We estimate that international cigarette industry volume, excluding China and the U.S., declined by 2.4% in 2015, a further moderation compared to the declines in 2013 and 2014.  For this year, we forecast a decline of 2% to 2.5% on the same basis. 
Our continued market share momentum in 2015 is clearly demonstrated on this slide with international share, excluding China and the U.S., up by 0.2 points to 28.7% in share growth in the EU, EEMA and Latin America and Canada regions. Our share in the Asia region was stable. 
Marlboro was a key driver of our market share momentum in 2015, increasing its international share, excluding China and the U.S. by 0.2 points to 9.6%. The brand had growing or stable share in all 4 regions and continue to benefit from the roll-out of architecture 2.0, which is now approaching 100 markets worldwide. 
Importantly, our 2015 share in the top 30 PMI OCI market grew by 0.7 points to 38%, with share up or essentially flat in 20 of its markets. These underscores the positive momentum of our business across the majority of our most profitable market. 
While pricing and market share gains are the foundation of our topline growth, we remain focused on effectively managing our cost base. Our mid-term targeted annual cost base increase is 1% to 3%, excluding RRPs and currency. 
In 2015, we decided to deploy additional investments, some of which will not recur in 2016 to support the strong momentum of our cigarette brand portfolio and accelerate the geographic expansion of. This resulted in a total cost base increase coming, excluding currency, of 3.6%, excluding RRPs, or 5.3%, including RRPs.
In 2016, we expect the total cost base, including RRPs, to increase by approximately 1%, excluding currency, reflecting productivity and cost saving programs and also helped by the moderating prices by key input, such as tobacco leaf, and nontobacco materials. 
Let me now discuss our performance in key geographies beginning with the EU region. Following declines of 7.3% and 3.1% in 2013 and 2014, respectively, there was a further moderation of the total cigarette industry volume decline to 0.9% in 2015. We attributed the moderation to improving economies, notably Southern Europe, a decline in the prevalence of illicit trade, less out-switching to the define cap category and a lower prevalence rate of the performance.
Our positive signature momentum in the region continued in 2015 with fourth quarter and full year share up by 0.3 points and 0.1 point, respectively. In the fourth quarter, our share increased in 5 of the 6 largest markets by cigarette industry volume, demonstrating the breadth of our share strength. 
As we have anticipated, our share in Italy was adversely impacted by the decline of Marlboro following its crossing of the EUR 5 per pack price point in the first quarter of 2015. Marlboro, L&M and Chesterfield further enforced their positions in the region's top 3 cigarette industry branch  by volume for the second consecutive year. 
Full year market share for Marlboro increased by 0.2 points to 18.9%, driven by strong performances in France, Germany and Spain. Share for L&M increased by 0.1 point to 6.9%, while Chesterfield grew by 0.2 share points to 5.8%. 
The moderating cigarette industry volume decline, coupled with our market share gains and strong pricing, resulted in adjusted OCI growth, excluding currency and acquisitions, of 4.6% in the EU region in 2015. This marked the regions first adjusted OCI increase from the same basis since 2009. 
In 2016, we forecast middle -- mid-single-digit currency-neutral adjusted OCI growth in the region. 
I will now turn to Russia, the largest market in our EEMA region where estimated cigarette industry volume declined by 8.4% in the fourth quarter and 6.2% for the full year. The declines were mainly due to significant excise tax-driven retail price increases, which we estimate average more than 20% year-over-year as well as lower consumer purchasing power.
Our full year 2015 market share increased by 0.9 points to 28.4%,  driven mainly by low price street and super low price mix, which benefited from advanced smoke down-trading and a wider distribution, particularly in the Eastern part of the country. Importantly, Parliament was up by 0.2 share point despite the overall premium segment decline of 0.7 points.
In January this year, the government implemented its planned 2016 excise tax increase resulting an average tax pass-on of around RUB 10 per pack or 14% on an industry weighted average base. In anticipation, we announced retail selling price increases across the majority of our portfolio of RUB 5  per pack last November and a further RUB 5  per pack this January, with the most recent increase likely to appear at retail in the second quarter.
Estimated cigarette industry volume in Turkey grew by 7.8% in the fourth quarter and 9% for the full year. This exceptional growth was driven mainly by a significant reduction in the prevalence of the illicit trade, which declined by over 5 percentage points to around 14% in 2016. Our market share in Turkey has strengthened, with the 3/4 of sequential growth. Fourth quarter share increased by 0.3 points to 44.2% and was driven by the superb performance of Marlboro, up by 1.2 points to 9.9%.  Marlboro shipment volume increased by 20.6% in the quarter. 
In January, the government increased the specific excise tax and the minimum excise tax, while living the ad valorem rate and changed, representing a further improvement in the excise tax structure. This resulted in a pass-on of around 40 cruise per pack at the retail level. We implemented retail sales price increase of 1 liter per pack across the majority of our portfolio, thus,, enhancing unit margin.
I will now touch on our Asia region beginning with Indonesia. Our estimated cigarette industry volume was stable in 2015 in line with our forecast and primarily due to the soft economy. While market share in the fourth quarter declined by 1 to 34.3%, reflecting the impact of retail price increases on our machine made brand, taken in advance of the January 2016 excise tax increase, our full year market share grew slightly to 35%. On an industry weighted average basis, the 2016 excise tax increase is around 15%. Despite the muted performance of the total market last year, we remain very optimistic about the profit growth opportunities in these key markets, thanks to its growing of population and rising income level.
In the Philippines, price gaps narrowed further in the fourth quarter following price increases at the bottom of the market. The gap between Marlboro and the superlow price brands of our primary local competitor now stands at around PHP 1 per cigarette, a narrowing of 50 centavos per cigarette or 33% since December 2013. The improved price gaps have been a key driver of a strong share performance. Based on Nielsen retail audit data, our full year 2015 share increased by 1.4 points to 73.4%. Marlboro was the primary driver of the share gain, increasing by an impressive 2.7 points to 21.1%. 
Fortune also gained share, growing by 0.7 points to 31.1%. Marlboro shipment volume increased by 18.8% in 2015 and drove a favorable mix. Encouragingly, we continued to improve profitability in this important market. 
In Japan, cigarette industry volume declined by 2.1% in 2015. This was less than what we had anticipated due mainly to trade inventory buildup 4 competitors recent new launches. Our cigarette market share performance was clearly below our expectations. Share declined by 0.6 points to 25.3% in 2015 due primarily to competitors' offerings in the new differentiated menthol segments.  Nevertheless, we remain confident in the long term outlook for our cigarette brand portfolio in Japan.
Turning to our products portfolio, let me briefly highlight the prior was that we made in 2015 on the commercialization of iQOS. During the year, we expanded the geographic presence of iQOS in our 2014 city launch market with the first wave of expansion in Japan reaching over 60% of the adult smoker population and the initial expansion in Italy beyond Milan to, Rome and Turin. We also launched iQOS in major cities across Switzerland and commenced city launches in Bucharest, Lisbon and Moscow. By the end of 2016, we expect iQOS to be present in key cities in around 20 markets globally. 
In Japan, which is by far our more advanced iQOS launch market in terms of geographic and adult smoke coverage, we estimate there were over 130,000 fully or predominantly converted iQOS users by the end of 2015. In the last week of December, we achieved an estimated offtake share of Marlboro sheet sticks of 1.1% in the expansion area and 1.7% in Tokyo. Importantly, our weekly offtake shares have grown steadily since the expansion began in September. Please note that share represent retail sales volumes for hit sticks as a percentage of the total estimated retail sales volume for cigarettes and heat sticks within a given geographic area. I look forward to sharing further the scientific and commercial progress that we've made with the iQOS during our presentation at the Cagney Conference later this month.
I will now cover our free cash flow, which increased by over $300 million in 2015 to reach $6.9 billion. This was a remarkable achievement considering the adverse currency impact of $1.9 billion for unmet earnings and was fueled by important working capital initiatives. As a reminder, the proceeds from the rights issue are not included in our free cash flow. In 2016, we forecast free cash flow broadly in line with last year's level, again, despite the anticipated adverse currency headwind at prevailing exchange rates.
We remain focused on rewarding our shareholders generously with the dividend currently serving as the primary use of our free cash flow. Last September, we increased our and annual dividend for the eighth consecutive year since the been in 2008, representing a total increase of approximately 122% at the compound annual growth rate of 12%. Our dividend yield at the end of last week was 4.5%. This is very attractive in comparison to the yields of our peer group company. 
In conclusion, 2015 was an excellent year for PMI, reflecting improved cigarette industry volume trends and very robust business fundamentals. Our superior cigarette brand portfolio, supported by a unique commercial organization, is driving strong pricing and continued market share gains. Marlboro is performing extremely well, with a continued rollout of the 2.0 architecture driving volume and share growth. We're very excited by our progress with the commercialization of iQOS, which is underscored by our favorable sheet stick offtake momentum in Japan. 
Our strong free cash flow continues to support our general dividends. Finally, the outlook for our business remains strong on a currency-neutral basis of 2016 EPS guidance reflects a growth rate of approximately 10% to 12% versus 2015 adjusted diluted EPS of $4.42. 
Thank you. Jacek and I will now be happy to answer your question.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: I just had 2 questions about pricing. I guess, first, André, I wanted to ask you about the pricing environment in Japan since Japan tobacco has requested a price increase on, so I was wondering if you made any similar requests on your portfolio? Or if you can talk through how you thinking about the opportunity there?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Clearly, the move from Japan Tobacco is encouraging, but appreciate I cannot make any further comment on pricing in Japan for obvious reasons.
componenttext: Okay. Clearly, the move from Japan Tobacco is encouraging, but appreciate I cannot make any further comment on pricing in Japan for obvious reasons.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, but that, I guess, would confirm that you haven't made any formal requests yet regardless of what your intentions might be? Okay. And then, I guess, just a broader question then. Your comments about the expectation for a 6% pricing variance this yea
componenttext: Okay, but that, I guess, would confirm that you haven't made any formal requests yet regardless of what your intentions might be? Okay. And then, I guess, just a broader question then. Your comments about the expectation for a 6% pricing variance this year implies about 1.6 billion in pricing, a bit below the 1.8 billion that we would typically think of as being sort of a midterm target and I know that Korea accounts for a portion of that gap. But if we exclude that, is there more an issue of rounding? Or do you see the potential for a more moderate level of pricing across the industry this year in light of macroeconomic weakness?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as -- you're right. You said Korea's the biggest swing because it swings about almost 1 point of pricing variance year-to-year compared to our previous years' revenues. Apart that, there's nothing in particular here that we should be reading. So we'
componenttext: Well, as -- you're right. You said Korea's the biggest swing because it swings about almost 1 point of pricing variance year-to-year compared to our previous years' revenues. Apart that, there's nothing in particular here that we should be reading. So we're very confident about the pricing environment. I think it's very positive and the excise tax environment is also positive, so no much change compared to the previous year.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, I guess, one other quick follow-up. Just within Indonesia, you mentioned the impact of crossing some critical pricing thresholds during the fourth quarter, is that a temporary price cap issue? Or something that could linger for a few quart
componenttext: Okay. And then, I guess, one other quick follow-up. Just within Indonesia, you mentioned the impact of crossing some critical pricing thresholds during the fourth quarter, is that a temporary price cap issue? Or something that could linger for a few quarters?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think this is temporary because sooner or later, others are crossing the critical points. Now that had more impact for us in this quarter. There is another phenomenon that is -- had a lot of increase activity, I would say, toward the end of the ye
componenttext: Well, I think this is temporary because sooner or later, others are crossing the critical points. Now that had more impact for us in this quarter. There is another phenomenon that is -- had a lot of increase activity, I would say, toward the end of the year in Indonesia, which is a number of competitive offerings that sell essentially 20 sticks per pack at the price of 60. Now this propositions typically are not viable longer term because if you remember, their excise tax in Indonesia is specific and on a per stick basis. But temporarily, you have some distortions because of these launches that should ease during the year. So that's essentially how what happened in Indonesia in the quarter.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Judy Hong of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Judy Hong of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: André, I wanted to get a little more color on the Russian market. Obviously, the shipment number in the fourth quarter was negatively impacted by inventory movement, but I think your share also was a little bit soft sequentially, so I'm just wondering wh
componenttext: André, I wanted to get a little more color on the Russian market. Obviously, the shipment number in the fourth quarter was negatively impacted by inventory movement, but I think your share also was a little bit soft sequentially, so I'm just wondering what's going on competitively. What are you seeing in terms of down-trading situation for -- in terms of the consumers? And then if you look out for 2016, your view in terms of how the industry volume would look like in Russia.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. First of all, let's start with this inventory. That has a little bit distorted the numbers of the fourth quarter and also for PMI. Essentially, it's a one-off adjustment because we decided to have our own warehouse in certain parts of the country ra
componenttext: Okay. First of all, let's start with this inventory. That has a little bit distorted the numbers of the fourth quarter and also for PMI. Essentially, it's a one-off adjustment because we decided to have our own warehouse in certain parts of the country rather than our distributor in order to facilitate its distribution. And on top of it, it helps working capital. So that's the reason we implemented, but there is no swings in there, that's one-off. In terms of what's happening in the market, in terms of total market, we appreciate it's a bit difficult to forecast. Last year, we had forecasted total market will decline by 9%. We ended up much better. We forecast again, given the magnitude of the increases, another 9% this year. If we come out better, we are all very happy. That's why we see the market. Now in terms of down trading, clearly, the down-trading is not dramatic, but we see -- if we look at the year, 2% share shifting from the meat segment and premium segment to essentially the low price segment, not the superlow, which is fairly stable. And we gained share in both premium, low and superlow segment, so I think we're well positioned overall in this environment. Now, again, Russia, you know the economy is a bit weak, the ruble has devalued, but overall, I think in terms of portfolio position, we are in a very good place and we've already taken pricing. So I feel pretty good about Russia overall if the ruble was a bit less volatile than it is. Have I answered your questions?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's helpful. And then, I guess, my second question is just in terms of the investments that you made in 2015 and, I guess, more specifically lapping of that in 2016 because your comment that your cost base is still going up 1% year-over-year impli
componenttext: Yes, that's helpful. And then, I guess, my second question is just in terms of the investments that you made in 2015 and, I guess, more specifically lapping of that in 2016 because your comment that your cost base is still going up 1% year-over-year implies that the incremental investments are actually staying in the cost base in '16, and so forth. So are these investments that you made in 2015 still continuing as it relates to some of these iQOS commercialization? Or you just gave us a little bit of a sense of kind of that lapping of that and cost still going up on a year-over-year basis?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. The -- what happened is -- first of all, the direction we gave for 2016 is 1% approximately up, including Reduced-Risk Products where we have obviously, incremental spending compared to 2015. Okay. That's the first item. And don't forget, our target
componenttext: Okay. The -- what happened is -- first of all, the direction we gave for 2016 is 1% approximately up, including Reduced-Risk Products where we have obviously, incremental spending compared to 2015. Okay. That's the first item. And don't forget, our target is 1% to 3% per year, excluding RRP. So just to facilitate your understanding, I would say that 40% of the incremental spending in the last quarter is nonrecurring in 2016 [indiscernible] Okay? And we clearly had also quite substantial incremental spending on iQOS in the fourth quarter. Now the nonrecurring items relate to, obviously, the implementation of the tobacco product in 2016, but some of the costs have to happen in 2015. It also some restructuring that we don't report under reported but in the normal earnings, plus some one-off items. So in total,, that's how I would see it. And I see -- I hope it helps you a little bit to understand.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: And so, I guess, what you're saying is that 60% of the incremental spending is still recurring, so you have that still in 2016. And then, obviously, the 1% total cost base going up also still include some of the commercialization spending related to iQOS
componenttext: And so, I guess, what you're saying is that 60% of the incremental spending is still recurring, so you have that still in 2016. And then, obviously, the 1% total cost base going up also still include some of the commercialization spending related to iQOS that were more implemental in nature?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Exactly.
componenttext: Exactly.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of James Bushnell of Exane.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I had 2, please. The first is on pricing in Europe. Obviously, you've had a good year there and the outlook was good in terms of OCI growth, but the pricing numbers seem to be a little softer than earlier in the year and I just wondered if you could give
componenttext: I had 2, please. The first is on pricing in Europe. Obviously, you've had a good year there and the outlook was good in terms of OCI growth, but the pricing numbers seem to be a little softer than earlier in the year and I just wondered if you could give us some color around that, please? And then the second question was on the retention rates you're getting in iQOS. The market share numbers you mentioned, some quite impressive, but I just wondered if the 30% retention rates you mentioned in the past was still consistent and how it was looking in Switzerland, for example, as well.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: In Europe, pricing in Europe is unchanged. What we make some difference in the quarter is if you remember in Germany in 2014, we took pricing in the middle of the year towards the second half. And in 2015, we anticipated earlier. So in the -- until the th
componenttext: In Europe, pricing in Europe is unchanged. What we make some difference in the quarter is if you remember in Germany in 2014, we took pricing in the middle of the year towards the second half. And in 2015, we anticipated earlier. So in the -- until the third quarter, we had 2  overlapping, amortization of pricing for the previous -- or from '14 and the pricing of '15, which we didn't have in the last quarter. But, as you know, we announced pricing in Germany, so we are back in the normal course. Okay  Try to explain this. Now I will give much more granularity about iQOS in Cagney. I don't want to steal the thunders of everybody, but the retention rates are much higher than the 30%. And that's very encouraging in Japan, actually.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: The next question comes from Bonnie Herzog from Wells Fargo.
componenttext: The next question comes from Bonnie Herzog from Wells Fargo.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question is on the EU. How sustainable are the improved trends you've been seeing throughout the region? And also, you continue to highlight a lower prevalence of per products in the EU, so I'm curious how much of a factor that's been to the impr
componenttext: My first question is on the EU. How sustainable are the improved trends you've been seeing throughout the region? And also, you continue to highlight a lower prevalence of per products in the EU, so I'm curious how much of a factor that's been to the improved combustible cig volume? Possibly these consumers have been switching back?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, I hope the trends in Europe are sustainable. I mean, while we forecast it's early in the year, but from everything you know, including pricing, we think it would maybe a bit lower than last year, a bit higher decline, but well above actually our 2 t
componenttext: Look, I hope the trends in Europe are sustainable. I mean, while we forecast it's early in the year, but from everything you know, including pricing, we think it would maybe a bit lower than last year, a bit higher decline, but well above actually our 2 to 3 secular decline that we anticipate. So to me, it looks fairly good in Europe, okay, and part of that is attributable, obviously, to a lower share of the cigarettes but also a little bit less illicit trade. And I think maybe because of the economy is also are improving, higher average daily consumption, which you can see in the trends, but that explains part of the volume.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then I have a question on a share repurchase program. So if your FX headwinds stays where its at, say, for the next couple quarters, is this an okay level for you to resume your share repurchases? Or do you need this headwind to
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then I have a question on a share repurchase program. So if your FX headwinds stays where its at, say, for the next couple quarters, is this an okay level for you to resume your share repurchases? Or do you need this headwind to reverse to be comfortable before you resume your buyback? I'm just trying to get a sense of what's going to give you comfort. Is it more visibility or lower headwind?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, lower headwind, obviously, because at current levels, it makes no sense to resume share repurchases. So once we see a reversal, then we can revisit the issue and I hope you will see it at some stage.
componenttext: Well, lower headwind, obviously, because at current levels, it makes no sense to resume share repurchases. So once we see a reversal, then we can revisit the issue and I hope you will see it at some stage.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's great. If I may ask one final quick question on your Marlboro 2.0 roll out, can you give us a sense of what percentage of your Marlboro 2.0 rolled out? Is it complete, I guess? And is there typically a lag before you see the full impact of thi
componenttext: Yes, that's great. If I may ask one final quick question on your Marlboro 2.0 roll out, can you give us a sense of what percentage of your Marlboro 2.0 rolled out? Is it complete, I guess? And is there typically a lag before you see the full impact of this on your overall Marlboro share?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think you are seeing the impact already and all the indications we have from the markets where we've already won more years in the market is all the fundamentals are improving, the perception is improving, the image is improving so it has worked v
componenttext: Well, I think you are seeing the impact already and all the indications we have from the markets where we've already won more years in the market is all the fundamentals are improving, the perception is improving, the image is improving so it has worked very well and actually beyond what I personally expected. So I don't know exactly weighted where we are. 100 markets, I think it's 95% of the volume of Marlboro already or something like that. And everywhere, we're seeing positive results. And if you remember, this is not just packaging. It's the whole communication of consumers, product improvement that were extremely well received by our consumers and also competitive smokers. [indiscernible]

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Chris Gurley of Stifel.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Chris Gurley of Stifel.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just ask, first of all, in relation to volume, which did weakened little bit sequentially in the fourth quarter. There are also unique factors that are leading to that and if you look at the strong performance in the first 9 months. As you look -- as yo
componenttext: I just ask, first of all, in relation to volume, which did weakened little bit sequentially in the fourth quarter. There are also unique factors that are leading to that and if you look at the strong performance in the first 9 months. As you look -- as you move into 2016, you've indicated global volumes down about the same rate that they were last year. Are there any markets in particular where we should kind of a keep watch out here? We're thinking about the big ones like Russia and Indonesia. Are those the ones you see being kind of the weakest here to lead out the year but improving throughout 2016?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, if you look overall, clearly, Russia, as I said, we have to make some assumptions. Last year, we're a bit positively surprised. I hope that's going to be the case, but we have to assume some decline in Russia. So we assumed, as I said, around
componenttext:
Yes. I mean, if you look overall, clearly, Russia, as I said, we have to make some assumptions. Last year, we're a bit positively surprised. I hope that's going to be the case, but we have to assume some decline in Russia. So we assumed, as I said, around 9% at this stage.
The -- on the positive side here, we have Korea because last year, we had quite impressive decline about apples-to-apples, I would say, 20%, which, this year, hopefully, we're not going to see. And clearly, we see improving trends during the year. So a lot on positive side. We had good upside in Turkey last year because of the illicit trade reduction plus increased consumption. I don't think we're going to see the same increment in Turkey this year, obviously. But as the year unfolds, we will know better. In markets where we're less impacted clearly, it's India that had a big decline last year. It was excised and VAT increases. As you know, we have minimal exposure there and Brazil. Brazil is likely to continue this year, obviously, because we have a combination of VAT tax increases in certain states because they have autonomy to decide about the VAT rates. And also, an excise tax increase that comes in 2 tranches in Brazil, one in May and one in December. And so that's where I see it. Now Indonesia, again, is a bit early days. As you know, on one side, we had a slightly soft economy. Price, the pass on of the excise tax in the previous years of about 5% of price increase equivalent. This year, it's 7.5%. Not dramatic, but slightly higher. And on the other side, we have -- on the positive side, we have minimum wage increases in the range of 11%. So how this is going to pay  at the end of the year is very difficult to predict. Conservative, we have assumed some decline, but we'll see if that materializes or not. And that's for the key markets. I don't know if I answered your.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That is helpful. I just have one quick follow-up, which is in relation to generally the global macro uncertainty. Some of the risk you see in some of these key markets. And you have some pricing going up. In a healthy rate just due to excise tax pas
componenttext: Okay. That is helpful. I just have one quick follow-up, which is in relation to generally the global macro uncertainty. Some of the risk you see in some of these key markets. And you have some pricing going up. In a healthy rate just due to excise tax pass along, are you seeing any changes in the last 2 city? Is it too early to tell for that? But I'm just curious if we're seeing that kind of weaker consumer reacting negatively to price increases in some of the key markets where you're taking those now?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, look, I must say that I'm positively surprised by elasticities rather than the opposite actually. They come more on our side than I thought. Now, again, some of the emerging markets we have to watch as the economy weakens, but we don't see many --
componenttext: I mean, look, I must say that I'm positively surprised by elasticities rather than the opposite actually. They come more on our side than I thought. Now, again, some of the emerging markets we have to watch as the economy weakens, but we don't see many -- any signs, I'm sorry, of this occurring at this it. So we'll keep you abreast of how is this going during the year, but I think we've baked in this in our forecast for total market for the year of 2% to 4%.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Understood. My second question have to do with the EU and with plain packaging. You called out some investments in the U.K. but you also called out negative mixed shifts. I'm wondering if you could just expand on some of the changes that you're making in
componenttext: Understood. My second question have to do with the EU and with plain packaging. You called out some investments in the U.K. but you also called out negative mixed shifts. I'm wondering if you could just expand on some of the changes that you're making in terms of your go-to-market as well as an update on the market landscape itself. If it's down-trading just in your portfolio or are we already starting to see down-trading in the U.K?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, first of all, in the U.K. in particular, we've essentially taken back our distribution from Imperial. So in the quarter, we had, particularly -- particular specific expenses due to this take back. And double cost, obviously, because we're still and
componenttext: Well, first of all, in the U.K. in particular, we've essentially taken back our distribution from Imperial. So in the quarter, we had, particularly -- particular specific expenses due to this take back. And double cost, obviously, because we're still and building up our own distribution. I don't see an acceleration in down-trading in the U.K. in terms of trends. And if we try to correlate this to plain packaging, clearly, there's no plain package in the U.K. I would say. But in general, because I get very often this question is U.K. going to become Australia? The first thing is the impact of plain packaging on Australia down-trading is extremely difficult to estimate, if any, because it's much more a question of pricing. Because if you remember, the margins at the bottom end of the market in Australia are still extremely high compared to the U.K. So I personally do not see an acceleration of the trends in the U.K. eventually plain packaging is implemented because there are already brands at very low margins at the bottom end of the market, and I don't think we'll see an acceleration of the trends. Now in the EU in general, I don't see much down trading here. Actually, the premium segment is stable and we grew share with Marlboro. So overall, I'm very positive about the trends in the European Union. And do not I forget that we have a portfolio with Marlboro, L&M and Chesterfield that is quite comfortably all price segments. So I think we are fairly confident about the prospects of the business in the European Union.

So that's a little bit the proportion we see today. 40% coming from our portfolio and 60% from competitive brands.

componenttext: Well, we are getting some part of the segment clearly due to the success of Marlboro blue, which is in our that segment. Okay. So there is some artificial boosting of that segment but, overall, we are making progress in that segment and with plans to further expand our presence in the segment.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question, I just want to talk a little bit about your cash flow and allocation. As you highlighted in your prepared remarks, you've done a great job keeping your cash flow steady despite the foreign currency headwinds. If you take the midpoint of
componenttext: My first question, I just want to talk a little bit about your cash flow and allocation. As you highlighted in your prepared remarks, you've done a great job keeping your cash flow steady despite the foreign currency headwinds. If you take the midpoint of your EPS guidance for 2016 though, your dividend payout is around 95%. So I was just curious if there's a level where you start to get a little uncomfortable? And kind of what lengths would go to on the dividend to just ensure that you could at least maintain, if not, increase it slightly like we saw last year?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, as I said, we will not decrease the dividend, okay? So yes, it is a high payout ratio and outlay. And given currencies, it will remain high for the next couple of years no matter what. I hope over time, as we grow profit and we grow cash flow, we'll
componenttext: Well, as I said, we will not decrease the dividend, okay? So yes, it is a high payout ratio and outlay. And given currencies, it will remain high for the next couple of years no matter what. I hope over time, as we grow profit and we grow cash flow, we'll come back to more normal levels. And if the currency stabilize, clearly, we'll recover much faster the return to normality, I would say. As we always said, maybe that sacrosanct, and we go to a large extent to maintain the dividend.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful. And just out of curiosity, is the 65% ratio, over the long term, obviously, is that kind of still in play? Or is that something that kind of been pushed out a little bit, just given the currency situation?
componenttext: That's very helpful. And just out of curiosity, is the 65% ratio, over the long term, obviously, is that kind of still in play? Or is that something that kind of been pushed out a little bit, just given the currency situation?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: This discussion about 65%, as I said, is a bit theoretical short term because we will remain, no matter what happens and what the currencies turn back to half of what they are today the dollar is to have. Once that -- the situation becomes a bit more clea
componenttext: This discussion about 65%, as I said, is a bit theoretical short term because we will remain, no matter what happens and what the currencies turn back to half of what they are today the dollar is to have. Once that -- the situation becomes a bit more clear where we'll go directionally, then we revisit this payout ratio and we may want to modify it. Kind of theoretical discussion today.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Very good. And I just want to dig a little bit into the Philippines. It sounds like you're happy with the progress there even with volume down as much as the category. It sounds like you're more than happy to trade the bottom end volume for the shar
componenttext: Okay. Very good. And I just want to dig a little bit into the Philippines. It sounds like you're happy with the progress there even with volume down as much as the category. It sounds like you're more than happy to trade the bottom end volume for the share gains on Marlboro at the top-end. So just curious if you could give a little bit color on how you feel about the Philippines. Have we turned the corner there and we're going to see improvement? Or is there still more work to do in that market?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: We definitely see improvements undoubtedly. Pricing at the bottom has increased. Compliance is increasing quite significantly. The tax tops had helped. And as the finally as of next year, we are at the final states of merging with. Overtime, we have the p
componenttext: We definitely see improvements undoubtedly. Pricing at the bottom has increased. Compliance is increasing quite significantly. The tax tops had helped. And as the finally as of next year, we are at the final states of merging with. Overtime, we have the possibility to unleash the profitability of the market also by growing Marlboro price. So overall, the prospects are extremely good in my view, good. And particularly, with this kind of price increases at the bottom, you will have some total market decline temporarily because it's 50% price increase over 1.5 years period. So you would expect some market decline. But overall, I think it looks pretty good, as I said. It's -- so I'm very happy with what's happening in the Philippines.

componenttext: Just a quick one for me. I was wondering in terms of projections for Indonesia industry volumes next year. So now you're saying 1% to 3% over the medium term. I'm just wondering if you could be a bit more specific now and for fiscal year '16.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the -- as I said, the -- it's slightly different forecast Indonesia at the beginning of the year. My view is, yes, there's a little bit of pricing, higher pricing this year because of higher tax. Last year, we had a 5% tax pass-on. This year, we're 7
componenttext: Yes, the -- as I said, the -- it's slightly different forecast Indonesia at the beginning of the year. My view is, yes, there's a little bit of pricing, higher pricing this year because of higher tax. Last year, we had a 5% tax pass-on. This year, we're 7.5%. The economy is a bit softer, but on the other side, minimum wages went up 11%. So how this is going to unfold is difficult for me to forecast. We have assume conservatively some slight market decline. Whether this materializes or not, we'll know over the next few months as the pass-on of the prices evolves. And that's how I see the total market for the moment. Long term, you're right. That's the way we look at the market, 1% to 3% growth.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just had a question on cost. I think you mentioned earlier on that there was some favorable leaf cost acetate and packaging. In dollar terms, could you give some indication of where those first major cost structure are headed?
componenttext: I just had a question on cost. I think you mentioned earlier on that there was some favorable leaf cost acetate and packaging. In dollar terms, could you give some indication of where those first major cost structure are headed?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, overall, we see stability in leaf prices. And on coal prices, we have some favorability year-to-year, but let's not forget that we run longer inventories. So on average, you see the impact in the years to come. So the outlook there in terms
componenttext: Well, I think, overall, we see stability in leaf prices. And on coal prices, we have some favorability year-to-year, but let's not forget that we run longer inventories. So on average, you see the impact in the years to come. So the outlook there in terms of leaf and clove is pretty good. And the clove crops fairly large so we could secure sufficient inventories at lower prices. Our overall cost, as I said, all in, including RRPs, should be in the range of 1%, probably slightly below. So we see a moderation clearly in the cost going forward. Now 1% of the total cost base based on 2015 is $150 million. That's what it is, okay?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: Switzerland for sure. Russia is still in discussion. But in the vast majority of the markets we have launched, it's lower rates than cigarette.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: And is that -- are you now pricing those heat sticks below cigarettes? Or are you still actually pricing at the same level in those markets?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: At this stage, we priced at parity with Marlboro, except for Switzerland where we are slightly lower. And in Russia where we used Parliament and on Marlboro and we're about the normal Parliament price. So work with different pricing models and different g
componenttext: At this stage, we priced at parity with Marlboro, except for Switzerland where we are slightly lower. And in Russia where we used Parliament and on Marlboro and we're about the normal Parliament price. So work with different pricing models and different go-to-market models at this stage and clearly with larger pool of best practices. So we accelerate future deployment and also improved cost efficiency as we become at least more intelligent about how these products markets.

componenttext: Okay. Basically, is a -- it is, this year is an important year because, as you mentioned, of the pending cases. We have WTO that the decision should come towards the second half of the year. And we have the U.K. High Court, which should rule before May, maybe earlier. So we'll know this important outcomes in the course of this year. So that's how we stand in terms of the pending cases at this stage.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016

componenttext: I was wondering if you could just comment on the outlook in Australia. I mean, the prime minister has been talking about continuing the 12.5% excise tax increases that have dented Australian volumes. Does that sound like a real risk? Or will there be some fiscal sensibility in the light of rising illicit trade in your view?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Feb 04, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, there are discussions of this nature and clearly, our explanations to the government is that they should put some stop in this out-of-cycle excise tax increases. This year, we have the last one. Now despite all these tax increases, which, as you kno
componenttext: Look, there are discussions of this nature and clearly, our explanations to the government is that they should put some stop in this out-of-cycle excise tax increases. This year, we have the last one. Now despite all these tax increases, which, as you know, are pretty substantial because they sometimes there are more than AUD 1 per pack on 20s equivalent, the total market was down only 2.6% in 2015, and I think that has remarkable elasticity. Now down-trading has continued although recently at the lower pace. And as far as we're concerned, our share has stabilized finally. We have increased our segment share for the segment, so we're in a position to influence the segment. And, essentially, I believe -- I mean, we also announced a price increase today in Australia. So the way I see Australia is it has been a slight drag on our OCI this year, much, much less than last year. Conservatively, we forecast another small drag next year, but we'll see now how this pricing unfolds. So that's the situation in Australia. Obviously, our objective is not to have the excise tax increase out of the normal ones that are the CPI indexation.

Have a great day.
