headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to the Philip Morris International First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is scheduled to last about 1 hour, including remarks by Philip Morris International management and the question-and-answer session. [Operato
componenttext:
Good day, and welcome to the Philip Morris International First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is scheduled to last about 1 hour, including remarks by Philip Morris International management and the question-and-answer session. [Operator Instructions]
I will now turn the call over to Mr. Nick Rolli, Vice President of Investor Relations and Financial Communications. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome, and thank you for joining us. Earlier today, we issued a press release containing detailed information on our 2016 first quarter results. You may access the release on our website at www.pmi.com or the PMI Investor Relations app. During our cal
componenttext:
Welcome, and thank you for joining us. Earlier today, we issued a press release containing detailed information on our 2016 first quarter results. You may access the release on our website at www.pmi.com or the PMI Investor Relations app. 
During our call today, we will be talking about results for the first quarter of 2016 and comparing them to the same period in 2015, unless otherwise stated. A glossary of terms, adjustments and other calculations as well as reconciliations to U.S. GAAP measures are at the end of today's webcast slides, which are posted on our website.
Reduced-Risk Products, or RRPs, is the term we use to refer to products with the potential to reduce individual risk and population harm in comparison to smoking cigarettes.
Today's remarks contain forward-looking statements and projections of future results. I direct your attention to the forward-looking and cautionary statements disclosure in today's presentation and press release for a review of the various factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from projections or forward-looking statements.
It's now my pleasure to introduce Jacek Olczak, our Chief Financial Officer. Jacek?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Nick, and welcome, ladies and gentlemen. As announced this morning, we are raising our 2016 reported diluted earnings per share guidance by $0.15 to a range of $4.40 to $4.50 at the prevailing exchange rates, that our vision is driven solely by
componenttext:
Thank you, Nick, and welcome, ladies and gentlemen. As announced this morning, we are raising our 2016 reported diluted earnings per share guidance by $0.15 to a range of $4.40 to $4.50 at the prevailing exchange rates, that our vision is driven solely by currency. Our guidance, therefore, now includes $0.45 of unfavorable currency that continues to represent a growth rate, excluding currency, of approximately 10% to 12% compared to our adjusted diluted EPS of $4.42 in 2015. 
We expect our currency-neutral adjusted diluted EPS growth in 2016 to be skewed towards the second half of the year and the fourth quarter in particular.
The $0.15 moderations in the currency impact on our guidance reflects the depreciations of the U.S. dollar against the number of our key currencies since we last provided guidance in mid-February. As shown on this slide, the Indonesian rupiah, Japanese yen and Russian ruble were the principal drivers of the variance. 
Let me now review our first quarter results, which, as expected, were heavily impacted by a difficult comparison versus our exceptionally strong first quarter results in 2016 that masked otherwise solid performance.
Organic cigarette volume in the quarter declined by 1.4% due mainly to the Asia region, principally Indonesia, Pakistan and the Philippines, and partially offset by the EU and Latin American and Canada regions as well as the favorable estimated impact of the leap year. As a reminder, our organic cigarette volume grew by 1.4% in the first quarter of 2015 [ph]. 
Our cigarette volume benefited from the strong performance of our international brands, where the top 7, including premium-priced Marlboro and above-premium Parliament, are growing. 
For the full year, we continue to forecast a decline in our organic cigarette volume of 1% to 1.5%. This compares favorably to our forecast of a cigarette industry volume decline, excluding China and the U.S., of 2% to 2.5%. 
On a currency-neutral basis, we recorded modest net revenue and adjusted diluted EPS growth in the quarter, while adjusted OCI declined slightly. As seen on this slide, our financial results faced particularly difficult comparisons in the quarter. The comparisons were challenging across all regions and even Asia, following the first quarter 2015 [ph] gain in Korea related to inventories built ahead of the January 2016 [ph]  Excise tax increase.
We recorded a pricing variance of $272 million in the first quarter, driven by the EU, EEMA and Latin America & Canada regions. Importantly, our pricing variance was slightly positive in the Asia region despite the unfavorable comparison related to the gain in Korea last year.
During the quarter, we announced or implemented price increases in a number of markets, notably Argentina, Germany, Indonesia and Russia as well as others shown on this slide. For the full year, we continue to anticipate the pricing variance of around 6% of our 2016 [ph] net revenues. 
Our cigarette market share, excluding China and the U.S., declined slightly in the first quarter due mainly to Asia region, notably Indonesia and Japan, partly offset by the EU and Latin America & Canada regions. Marlboro's market share was stable on the same basis, with strong growth in the Asia, EU and LAC regions, offset by a decline in the EEMA region, due largely to North Africa.
Let me now discuss our regional results, beginning with the EU, where first quarter cigarette industry volume increased by 0.6%.
The strong industry performance continues to reflect the improving economies, notably in the Southern Europe, a decline in illicit trade, less out-switching for the fine cut category and a lower prevalence of e-vapor products. We also attribute some of the growth to the estimated favorable impact of immigration in select geographies.
Our positive momentum continued in the quarter, with regional cigarette share increasing by 0.6 points to 38.7%. Marlboro, L&M and Chesterfield, the top 3 selling industry cigarette brands in the region, all grew share in the quarter, underscoring the growth trend of our portfolio.
We are progressing well with the commercializations of iQOS in the region. In Switzerland, iQOS is currently present in 6 key cities, representing approximately 1/3 of total cigarette industry volume. During the last week of March, we reached the HeatStick offtake share of 0.8% in the [indiscernible], the highest level since the launch last August. At 1.9% market share, HeatStick offtake share was even higher in the French-speaking part of the launch area, where we have concentrated the majority of our [indiscernible] thus far.
In Italy, HeatStick offtake share has been stable at around 0.2% in the expansions area covering Bologna, Milan, [indiscernible], Rome and Turin. We recently launched the latest version of the iQOS device and are refocusing our market approach and touch points to increase our effectiveness of our engagement. This includes the rollout of iQOS embassies, which leverage the iQOS flagship store concept that we have successfully deployed in Japan.
Turning to the EEMA region. We faced particularly difficult comparisons this year, following currency-neutral net revenue and adjusted OCI growth of 14.1% and 24.3%, respectively, in the first quarter of 2015 [ph]. 
We also faced challenges in some of our key EEMA markets. In Ukraine, the overall economic and geopolitical uncertainty contributed to a very competitive pricing environment, which began in late 2015 and is now starting to improve. In Algeria, sizable excise tax-driven retail price increases over the past year of approximately 21%, on an industry weighted average basis, put pressure on Marlboro share, though this was partly offset by the strong performance of L&M. We expect better performance in this market as the year unfolds and remain confident in the outlook for the region this year. 
In Russia, cigarette industry volume declined by 6% in the quarter, a resilient performance given the significant retail price increases over the past year of approximately 23% on an industry weighted average basis.
For the full year, we maintained our forecast for cigarette industry volume decline of around 9%. 
Our market share declined by 0.2 points to 27.8% in the February quarter-to-date period, which we attribute mainly to price increases for some of our products that reached adult smokers sooner than competitors' price increases.
The downtrading in our portfolio from the medium to lower-price segment was consistent with the broader industry trend. 
Our strong pricing resulted in another quarter of solid, double-digit, currency-neutral OCI growth, and we are targeting similar growth for the full year on the same basis.
In Turkey, cigarette industry volume grew by 11.7% in the first quarter, as the industry continued to benefit from a significant reduction in the illicit  trade. Our February quarter-to-date market share increased by 0.6 points to 43.9%, driven by the continued strength of Marlboro, which grew by 1.1 points to 10%. 
Currency-neutral OCI growth in the quarter was exceptional and benefited from our January price increases as well as higher cigarette volume, driven by the growth in both industry volume and market share.
Moving to the Asia region. Our financial results were similarly impacted by a difficult comparison, due principally to the gain in Korea that I mentioned earlier. Beyond this distortion, there were a number of positive developments in the quarter. Notably, Marlboro's regional cigarette market share and volume increased by 0.5 points and 5.1%, respectively. 
In Australia, the super-low price segment is showing signs of stabilization, and March price increases for cigarette brands in this segment were above the excise tax pass-on. Importantly, we grew our share in the quarter by 1.1 points to 36.4%, driven by Bond Street and Choice.
In the Philippines, price cuts were stable throughout the quarter and represented a significant narrowing compared to the first quarter of 2015. The narrowed price gaps between Marlboro and lower-price brands continue to support our strong overall share, which increased by 1.4 points to 73.6%.
Let me now cover some specific Asia region markets in more detail. In Indonesia, cigarette industry volume declined by 5.9% in the first quarter, due to mainly -- due mainly to the soft economy and the impact of industry weighted average price increases of around 11% in the quarter, which exceeded the inflation rate of around 4%.
The decline also reflects a difficult comparison versus the first quarter of 2015 in which cigarette industry volume grew by 6%. Our market share declined by 1.3 points to 34.1%, due primarily  to share loss in the machine-made kretek segment, reflecting the growth of competitors' plus 4 cigarette offers value propositions with 4 extra cigarettes per pack. The decline was partly offset by our favorable performance in the hand-rolled kretek segment, where we solidified our leadership positions and grew segment share. We expect our share loss in the quarter to be a temporary phenomenon, and we have a number of initiatives in place to restore growth, particularly in the machine-made kretek segment.
For the full year, we forecast a cigarette industry volume decline of 1% to 2% and are targeting double-digit currency-neutral OCI growth.
In Japan, cigarette industry volume increased by 2.3% in the first quarter, driven by estimated retail trade inventory movements and adult smoker purchases ahead of price increases for select competitors' brands effective April 1.
Excluding this favorable inventory movement, we estimate that cigarette industry volume was essentially flat. 
Our cigarette market share declined by 1.6 points, due to inventory movements, competitors' offerings in the differentiated menthol taste segment and cannibalization by HeatSticks. We continue to invest behind the pipeline of innovations for our cigarette brand portfolio, including the national rollout of Parliament Crystal Blast in March.
As you may be aware, last week, we submitted an application to the Ministry of Finance for approval to increase the prices of nearly all Lark variance and some Parliament variants by JPY 7 per pack effective August 1 -- by JPY 10 per pack effective August 1. This variant represents approximately 45% of our cigarette volume in Japan. 
We are very excited by the performance of iQOS in Japan. As seen on this cart, weekly HeatStick offtake share increased steadily for the end of the first quarter, reaching 2.4% in the expansion area and 3.4% in Tokyo during the last week of March. 
On a quarterly basis, we recorded a HeatStick offtake share of 1.8% in the expansions area and estimate that this equates to a first quarter national market share of approximately 0.8%. 
The positive HeatStick offtake share momentum is a clear indicator that iQOS is resonating with Japanese adult smokers. Importantly, we are seeing a steady increase in the proportion of iQOS purchasers who have predominately or fully converted to it, reaching approximately 60% in February. 
In addition, I am pleased to confirm that yesterday, we commend the full expansion of iQOS national.
Let me conclude my comments on regional performance with the Latin America & Canada region, where our cigarette volume increased by 2.4% in the quarter, driven principally by Mexico, partly offset by Argentina.
Regional market share increased by 1.1 points to 39.3%, reflecting growth in the majority of our key markets. Marlboro had a very strong quarter, with a share up by 1.2 points and volume growth of 8.5%.
Our strong net revenue and adjusted OCI growth rates, excluding currency, were driven mainly by pricing in Argentina and Canada.
In conclusion, our first quarter results were in line with our expectations with year-on-year performance adversely impacted by a difficult comparison with the first quarter of 2015. Nevertheless, the underlying fundamentals of our business continue to be strong. 
We are making exciting progress with the commercialization of iQOS, which is demonstrated, in particular, by the steady weekly growth in HeatStick's offtake share in Japan. Importantly, our iQOS conversion model is clearly working. We remain focused on generating strong free cash flow and continue to forecast full year 2016 free cash flow to be broadly in line with last year's level.
The outlook for 2016 remains strong. To reflect currency movements, we are raising our 2016 reported diluted EPS guidance, which, on a currency-neutral basis, continues to reflect the growth rate of approximately 10% to 12% versus 2015 adjusted diluted EPS of $4.42. 
Thank you, and I am now happy to answer your questions.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Bill Marshall with Barclays.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Bill Marshall with Barclays.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to first dig in on Indonesia a little bit. You talked about targeting double-digit profit growth in that market this year. When we think about Indonesia over the long term, is this -- should we think about it a little differently, where mayb
componenttext: I just wanted to first dig in on Indonesia a little bit. You talked about targeting double-digit profit growth in that market this year. When we think about Indonesia over the long term, is this -- should we think about it a little differently, where maybe it will be more of a profit growth markets and less of a kind of volume revenue market going forward? Or is this just a onetime factor in 2016 and then maybe we'll get a little bit more volume growth in the out years?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Bill, to be frank, actually, I think, in Indonesia, again, it's all 3. It can be a volume revenue and a bottom line OCI growth target. We still remain confident, in the longer run, Indonesia total market can be in the growth rate of somewhere around
componenttext: Well, Bill, to be frank, actually, I think, in Indonesia, again, it's all 3. It can be a volume revenue and a bottom line OCI growth target. We still remain confident, in the longer run, Indonesia total market can be in the growth rate of somewhere around 1%, 1% to 2%. We have said it on a number of occasions in the past, that depends on the macroeconomic factors, which may impact temporarily the purchasing power, et cetera. The market may have some slowdown. I think what we observed, what we forecast to observe this year, due to the a bit of a softer -- due to the softer economy, et cetera, Indonesia maybe go into some decline this year. But pricing remains strong. The cost outlook for Indonesia, I mean, it seems pretty positive. And therefore, we're very confident that this year, is in the years in the past, I mean, Indonesia not only will be grow double-digit bottom line but also going to remain very significant contributor to overall PMI performance. So I'm very positive on Indonesia, both in the short and longer term. But as many developing economies, there might have some periods of relative slowdown and then acceleration.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's great. And just a quick follow-up. On Japan, just can you walk through the decision not to apply for price increases on Marlboro?
componenttext: That's great. And just a quick follow-up. On Japan, just can you walk through the decision not to apply for price increases on Marlboro?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean,  I think it's pretty obvious. If you look at what the price increase of our key competitor has announced earlier this quarter. So we're somehow also reacting to the price moves announced or registered by others. So I think it's pretty obviou
componenttext: Well, I mean,  I think it's pretty obvious. If you look at what the price increase of our key competitor has announced earlier this quarter. So we're somehow also reacting to the price moves announced or registered by others. So I think it's pretty obvious why we just selected that part of the portfolio.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Vivienne Azor with Calvin.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Vivienne Azor with Calvin.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So my first question has to do with the negative mix shift that we saw in the quarter. While I appreciate the more you did price realization, the negative mix, in particular, in the EU, comes as a little bit of a surprise given that the momentum that we'r
componenttext: So my first question has to do with the negative mix shift that we saw in the quarter. While I appreciate the more you did price realization, the negative mix, in particular, in the EU, comes as a little bit of a surprise given that the momentum that we're seeing in Marlboro. So can you expand on that a little bit, please?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, actually, if I talk historically, I mean, you had a relatively good mix, a relatively low mix. I think it's maybe some movements in timing of movements between the countries. I think the biggest challenge, which we have to compete with, if
componenttext: Well, I think, actually, if I talk historically, I mean, you had a relatively good mix, a relatively low mix. I think it's maybe some movements in timing of movements between the countries. I think the biggest challenge, which we have to compete with, if you like, in the quarter was essentially coming the lack of a pricing variance from Korea. And that's on a total PMI basis and obviously weighted quite largely on the Asia regions. If I were to add a lack of the pricing extra gain from Korea, our revenue was being 4.5% growth territory, and this is still despite a pretty challenging comp from Q1 over last year. So I think it's mostly the price, which was driving the revenues and obviously also the bottom line. And then obviously, you have a couple of accounts, which were coming from outside EU region, which were coming from the volume. I mean, the Russia, both total market and especially PMI performance, completely different comps. And Indonesia and Asia also contributed.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then on iQOS. Given the strong demand that you've seen in Japan and the delay in the national launch, which, I guess, occurred yesterday, how are we thinking about the incremental market introductions that are anticipated for the
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then on iQOS. Given the strong demand that you've seen in Japan and the delay in the national launch, which, I guess, occurred yesterday, how are we thinking about the incremental market introductions that are anticipated for the year? Will the strong demand in Japan perhaps delay some of the, I think, 13 markets that you're targeting by year-end?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we target 20 markets to be present with iQOS on the city level, on the national level, by the year-end. I mean, clearly, the Japanese performance is -- I could say it like this. It comes with our expectations, and our expectations are very high, and
componenttext: Well, we target 20 markets to be present with iQOS on the city level, on the national level, by the year-end. I mean, clearly, the Japanese performance is -- I could say it like this. It comes with our expectations, and our expectations are very high, and our expectations are rising as we speak. So clearly, the focus today is to satisfy the full demand in Japan. I would like to remind that we're operating this year with not fully accessible capacity because the factory in Bologna greenfield construction will be completed somewhere towards the end of this year. But so far, I think our plan absolutely valid for this year. And we're very excited not only by Japan. We have said -- like I said in my presentation, also very good results, which we achieved so far in the French-speaking part of Switzerland, but it's very encouraging. And in all places, which we have make iQOS available today, we're approaching or actually exceeding the conversions rate, which we're, at this stage, achieving an Japan. So it's a lot of fine-tuning of the conversion model, of the route to market, route to consumer. And I think we're on the very strong progress of the site. So we're very encouraged by the results.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Matthew Grainger with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Matthew Grainger with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So as we think about the cadence of profit growth and earnings growth this year, clearly, we're still in a period of more accelerated rollout costs behind iQOS. I don't know if it's -- I may be asking for too much detail here, but can you give us a rough
componenttext: So as we think about the cadence of profit growth and earnings growth this year, clearly, we're still in a period of more accelerated rollout costs behind iQOS. I don't know if it's -- I may be asking for too much detail here, but can you give us a rough sense for how material the step-up in investment was as a headwind to earnings growth this quarter or how it compares to Q4? And you mentioned in the release, the earnings growth profile being more second half-weighted and Q4-weighted. So just wondering if you could sort of help set expectations for Q2.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Matthew, you're always asking for a lot of details, right? Look, let me put it this way. Absent the iQOS partially comes but also increased investment, I guess the costs for the quarter would come about flat. Essentially, that would be flat. So all the co
componenttext: Matthew, you're always asking for a lot of details, right? Look, let me put it this way. Absent the iQOS partially comes but also increased investment, I guess the costs for the quarter would come about flat. Essentially, that would be flat. So all the cost growth in the quarter, one can attribute to the  investments behind iQOS. It's obviously ex currency but always on ex currency basis. To give a bit more light into how we see the quarters going forward, we still -- to confirm that our outlook for the total costs for  the year, and this is all inclusive again on ex currency basis, the conventional and RRP, Reduced-Risk Product,  on ex currency basis, the cost outlook still remains at about 1% for the full year. So we'll have obviously some comps issues in the quarters. If you look at the pacing of our growth rates, if I take it on an EPS level, second, third, fourth quarter, look, as much as we would be explaining the difficult comps in the Q1 of this year, I mean, clearly, we'll have a different situation, 180 degrees different situations in the Q4 of this year. So obviously, one should expect a quite a strong, very strong actually growth rate and EPS level in the Q4. And Q2 and Q3, we will be going somewhere below obviously the guidance, which we gave for the full year. This will very much also depend on the timing of some expenses and et cetera. I think revenue line is going to be cruising closer to what we said this for the full year, so somewhere in the corridor of 5% -- 5% to 6% quarter this year versus the quarters of the last year. We should see the evolutions of the revenue. So it's much more the differences, which we have in the comps coming from the investment, partially behind the conventional, but very much obviously driven by the deployment of iQOS.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. That's a good amount of detail. And just follow-up on the EU. As we think about the growth outlook for volumes and mix in the region, how do you think about the potential for the favorable immigration impact that you mentioned to potentially su
componenttext: All right. That's a good amount of detail. And just follow-up on the EU. As we think about the growth outlook for volumes and mix in the region, how do you think about the potential for the favorable immigration impact that you mentioned to potentially support stable volumes over a longer period of time or potentially positive volumes?  Because it continues to be more constructive on the volume level than we would have expected.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, the way we look -- I look at the EU region is I still would maintain that all other parameters staying equal, EU is in a sort or should be in a sort of secular decline over 1% to 2% per annum, okay? And I think, obviously, when you have the recovery
componenttext: Look, the way we look -- I look at the EU region is I still would maintain that all other parameters staying equal, EU is in a sort or should be in a sort of secular decline over 1% to 2% per annum, okay? And I think, obviously, when you have the recovery of the illicit trade, which you have much less pressure from the fine cut products and recovered from electronic e-vapor products, electronic cigarettes, I mean, we could see that these trends could be better than the secular trend. And then we're all reading, watching the same news, and we all hear about the immigrations. I mean, these things are getting into a bit the larger scale at least recently. It's difficult to put a number, how much does this contribute to the volume fluctuations. But this will be difficult to deny, at this stage at least, that there is some impact of the trade. We recognize it in my remarks, but as much as I am willing, you know me, on occasions to give more details, I can't offer you a number. But there is some impact. There is some positive impact on EU from immigration.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from of the line of Michael Lavery with CLSA.
componenttext: Our next question comes from of the line of Michael Lavery with CLSA.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: You mentioned the cost outlook in Indonesia is favorable, but there is increasing cost. We're seeing maybe about 20-or-so percent. Is that adding any pressure? Or is that just because you're able to source it in ways that you're not exposed to us much of
componenttext: You mentioned the cost outlook in Indonesia is favorable, but there is increasing cost. We're seeing maybe about 20-or-so percent. Is that adding any pressure? Or is that just because you're able to source it in ways that you're not exposed to us much of that? What's the outlook there? Is that something which we should be looking, watching out for over the rest of the year?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. I think, actually, the cost in Indonesia, if you take this -- what's in the market, it's somehow at the level -- somewhere at the level of last year, actually better off. Remember that what hits our P&L is the costs going through the balance sheet for
componenttext: No. I think, actually, the cost in Indonesia, if you take this -- what's in the market, it's somehow at the level -- somewhere at the level of last year, actually better off. Remember that what hits our P&L is the costs going through the balance sheet for the inventories, right? So if you -- obviously, for obvious reasons, we'll not disclose how long inventories do we have, but that the impact is not medically going for the P&L. It takes some while to impact our costs. But the input cost in general for Indonesia is, at this stage, pretty positive, I mean, a stable positive. So therefore, another compounding factor, compounding factors supporting our [indiscernible] that the Indonesia, our business in Indonesia can grow at a double-digit bottom line.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And we've seen good [indiscernible] pretty aggressive pricing late in the fourth quarter. But then you're still seeing your share under some pressure in this quarter. And you specifically mentioned some machine-made discounting. What
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And we've seen good [indiscernible] pretty aggressive pricing late in the fourth quarter. But then you're still seeing your share under some pressure in this quarter. And you specifically mentioned some machine-made discounting. What's the pricing environment look like? Is it other competitors that are putting pressure on? Or were their pricing increases not maybe broad enough? Or can you just dissect a little bit some of your share moves and what you expect over the course of the rest of the year?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. I think everyone is -- we don't see anything abnormal in speed of frequency in the light of the pricing being taken in Indonesia. Obviously, we have some positive adjustments due to the size of the relatively higher size of excise tax on their pass-
componenttext: Sure. I think everyone is -- we don't see anything abnormal in speed of frequency in the light of the pricing being taken in Indonesia. Obviously, we have some positive adjustments due to the size of the relatively higher size of excise tax on their pass-on, which industry was confronted this year. So I think, as an industry, we follow what the competition price moves out there. It's nothing really abnormal taking theirs. Obviously, the prices are going a little bit higher due to, as I mentioned, higher pass-on to be passed to consumers. Now 4 extra stick price segments or some per-stick discounting, which has happened there, the segment of extra 4 sticks in the pack, which was sold at the price of the competitors' product with the 4 sticks life was, therefore, some time. I think until the relatively late, okay, let's say, maybe second half of last year, the segment wasn't about 3% to 4%, if I'm not mistaken, size of the total market. So it is a segment that's not very sizable segment. The other, very sizable segment in the market. This accelerated, I think, due to some offerings or introductions from some competitors. We're not very active in the segment. I think the recent -- the most recent reading of the size of the segment is somewhere in the range of 9%, maybe slightly above 9%. So it's growing. It accelerated the growth recently. I think in that environment, where the consumer is confronted with the frequent price increases and maybe of a slightly  higher nature than in the past, clearly, some form of the price also discounting. I mean, it might be attractive to some consumers. So that puts, obviously, especially if you look at to the quarterly shares, monthly shares, they put a pressure on some of our propositions in the market. But I mean, overall, I would say it's all on the situation.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then just lastly, can you talk a little bit about Australia? You mentioned share gains there, but it sounds like there's still is negative mix and, of course, volume decline. Are you seeing that as an overall drag on profitabilit
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then just lastly, can you talk a little bit about Australia? You mentioned share gains there, but it sounds like there's still is negative mix and, of course, volume decline. Are you seeing that as an overall drag on profitability? Or are the share gains able to have some pricing able to give a lift? Or what's the outlook there really just in terms of how it's shaping up?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: We're still comparing ourselves to relatively late part of our period of the performance in Asia -- sorry, in Australia. I think Q4 2014, first quarter of 2015, we still were a little bit in a more -- we're in a more difficult situation in Australia. Aust
componenttext: We're still comparing ourselves to relatively late part of our period of the performance in Asia -- sorry, in Australia. I think Q4 2014, first quarter of 2015, we still were a little bit in a more -- we're in a more difficult situation in Australia. Australia is not a drag, neither in the quarter, not able to think in our outlook for the full year. That's sort of a drag, not even near the drag, which we have had in the past periods. I mean, the situation, I think, the price increases are pleased, taking its face value as it is now, i.e. the price announcements versus the excise increase, we'll have to see how that develops. But it seems that the dynamics in terms of the discount growth segment, combined with this price increases from us and competitors might be a couple of steps in the right direction. So I'm getting very cautiously more optimistic on Australia, but still some time to go. I think that the worst is definitely far behind us.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Bonnie Herzog with Wells Fargo.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jacek, I just have one quick question first on the pricing in Japan. When do you expect to hear feedback when your application? And is this price increase factored into your guidance?
componenttext: Jacek, I just have one quick question first on the pricing in Japan. When do you expect to hear feedback when your application? And is this price increase factored into your guidance?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we should expect something as always in Japan. I think we have a 90 days, if I'm not mistaken. That's about the time period when the [indiscernible] has to come with a decision. And to be very frank with you, the price in Japan, the price increase
componenttext: I think we should expect something as always in Japan. I think we have a 90 days, if I'm not mistaken. That's about the time period when the [indiscernible] has to come with a decision. And to be very frank with you, the price in Japan, the price increase of JPY 10 on these 2 [ph] brands, is not fully factored in our guidance. But let me remind you that if the price is high, they will going to the market in the later part of the year. And as you know, guidance for the number of variable components, and this will -- we'll see how it unfolds. But actually, this pricing is not in our guidance.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that helps. And then the EU Tobacco Products Directive, which will be implemented in May, just curious to hear from you some of the key issues and concerns. And then what are you doing to mitigate those? And then also the costs associated with compl
componenttext: Okay, that helps. And then the EU Tobacco Products Directive, which will be implemented in May, just curious to hear from you some of the key issues and concerns. And then what are you doing to mitigate those? And then also the costs associated with complying, were those above your expectations, Jacek?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the part of this cost we have incurred in Q3, very much Q4 actually of last year, I mean, as you remember, we've had -- we made decisions actually to preempt that spending, and some of these preparations called when it comes to the product, machines
componenttext: Well, the part of this cost we have incurred in Q3, very much Q4 actually of last year, I mean, as you remember, we've had -- we made decisions actually to preempt that spending, and some of these preparations called when it comes to the product, machines, et cetera. It's a number of a cost buckets, which we have to cover. We decided already to take in 2015 -- into 2015. I think we were prepared. These are the biggest challenges that, obviously, this directive does not heat due to the transition period, which were put by the different members. The transition periods are different in the different members. So logistically, it is a quite an exercise. They might be -- nothing has to happen, but it might be that there will be some distortions on a shipment level. I don't think it's been obviously part of the consumption or retail offtake, but it might be some difference on a shipment level in the quarters going forward. But it's difficult, frankly speaking to predict. There are a number of formats, which will have to be replaced. One format has to cease its existence at retail level, has to be replaced by the same cigarette but in a different pack format, et cetera. So it's more of the logistics supply chain type of a stretch at this stage, rather than nothing else. I don't think structurally is going to change over our outlook in terms of the performance but on the top and bottom- line for the EU region.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then in terms of Russia, I was actually hoping you could drill down just a little bit further on your business there. You took a price increases in that market. So I guess I'd like to hear the impact of that as well as then your expectation for
componenttext: Okay. And then in terms of Russia, I was actually hoping you could drill down just a little bit further on your business there. You took a price increases in that market. So I guess I'd like to hear the impact of that as well as then your expectation for possible share gain in this market and, essentially, your outlook for the remainder of the year in terms of Russia.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I mean, I'll start with the total market. I mean, the first quarter again, as many quarters of last year came pretty stronger and total industry size. I think 6% is clearly on the low side of one could expect from the market with 20%, 23% on a weighted ba
componenttext: I mean, I'll start with the total market. I mean, the first quarter again, as many quarters of last year came pretty stronger and total industry size. I think 6% is clearly on the low side of one could expect from the market with 20%, 23% on a weighted basis price increases. So clearly, the elasticity is still on a, what I've been used to call, attractive side, i.e. minus 0.3, minus 0.5, somewhere in this territory. That's good. Market share, I mean, it seems that this year, we are a little bit faster than competitions with rolling out the prices or maybe actually competition is a bit slower versus us in lowering out the prices, presumably for proper description of the situation. Russia also appears this year versus pretty strong share advancements last year. So 20, 30 basis points of share pressure. I mean, it doesn't really disturb us dramatically. The more important is the total volume of industry somehow seems on a stronger side to the price increases. Portfolio and the downtrading in the market, so our brand's performance and the downtrading in the market, I mean, it goes, frankly speaking, in line with what we're expecting. It's not -- we don't see acceleration of a downtrading. You have this medium to value segment, sort of 1 up to 2 share points year-on-year fluctuations difference there. I mean, our brands performing in their respective segments, pretty strong. So I think the outlook in terms, again, on the profitability, which, I guess, is the most important at this stage, I mean, it's pretty positive. And yes, we might have some sort of vocational share pressure, but it is more, as I said also in my remarks, it's more the timing of those products are going to heat first in the market with a price increase. Nothing structural.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016

componenttext: Okay. And just one final quick question on iQOS. I just wanted to confirm that you're on track to file the 2 application to the FDA in the fall of this year.

componenttext: We're targeting to apply towards the end of this year, that's correct.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Judy Hong with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So one, just going back to Japan, Jacek. I mean, the market share trend there continues to be soft. And just wanted to get a little bit more color just in terms of your effort to improve cigarette market share in that market. And are you increasing lookin
componenttext: So one, just going back to Japan, Jacek. I mean, the market share trend there continues to be soft. And just wanted to get a little bit more color just in terms of your effort to improve cigarette market share in that market. And are you increasing looking at that market with iQOS now more holistically and trying to kind of look at the total market share, including iQOS? And in markets like Tokyo, where your iQOS market share is pretty strong, is that where you also see a bit more impact on those combustible market share?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: While, I mean, we try to look at this stage, I guess at 2 [ph] product propositions apparently. There are challenges which we are facing on a combustible business, and we're trying to get the right portfolio of innovations into the market to address the p
componenttext: While, I mean, we try to look at this stage, I guess at 2 [ph] product propositions apparently. There are challenges which we are facing on a combustible business, and we're trying to get the right portfolio of innovations into the market to address the problem. I think the launch in the Parliament Crystal Glass towards the end of first quarter, just an average as we're bringing to address the pressure, which we have in this low taste menthol category, the capsule product, et cetera. So by no means we are refocusing our attention from a combustible to iQOS. Now having said so, the story of iQOS is getting more and more exciting every time we look at the results from Japan. Now I have to admit one thing. This is not that we are trying to mask some of our performance in the conventional of business. However, 0.8, if I take the offtake shares from the places where iQOS is available today in Japan and recalculate this to have an equivalent in market sales market share compared to what we reported a conventional business, 0.8 in the quarter, knowing that there is cannibalizations from my own portfolio and very much skewed towards Marlboro, I would guess, if we just assume that half of that or close to half of that was for the cannibalization, clearly, iQOS already has an impact also on my conventional share performance. If I will just, as I said earlier, apply to use that number to explain the market share performance of Marlboro, about half of the Marlboro decline, I could -- i should actually attribute to the iQOS cannibalization. It's a good cannibalization. However, this is what we might observe for some time. So Judy, we're trying to address both conventional and both RRPs, but we do have to recognize that there might be some interactions between above categories.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I had a couple of questions on FX. One is just if I look at Q1, the sales impact from FX in Europe was much more sizable than what the euros sort of decline on a year-over-year basis would have shown. So I'm wondering if there's any sort of
componenttext: Okay. And then I had a couple of questions on FX. One is just if I look at Q1, the sales impact from FX in Europe was much more sizable than what the euros sort of decline on a year-over-year basis would have shown. So I'm wondering if there's any sort of hedging you've started to do more on the euro side or if there's anything that I missing just in terms of FX impact on sales in Europe or in EU.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: No. No, I don't think, Judy, you're missing anything. We didn't do anything on the euro for the hedges, which had an impact. I think it's just -- I guess it's just the timing. We always operate with the sort of a quarterly numbers, but at the end of the d
componenttext: No. No, I don't think, Judy, you're missing anything. We didn't do anything on the euro for the hedges, which had an impact. I think it's just -- I guess it's just the timing. We always operate with the sort of a quarterly numbers, but at the end of the day, some of the parts of the monthly exchange rates, which we use for the us our pinafore income statement. Maybe it's just a timing of -- euro was pretty volatile or pretty dynamic in terms of the depreciation last year. Maybe it's just the comps between the both quarters.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then the other question on FX was just when I look at your guidance for the full year the $0.15 favorability, there's some favorability on the yen movement. But it seems like some of the hedging that you put on also limits that impact. So can yo
componenttext: Okay. And then the other question on FX was just when I look at your guidance for the full year the $0.15 favorability, there's some favorability on the yen movement. But it seems like some of the hedging that you put on also limits that impact. So can you just remind us where you are hedged on the yen and what that impact would be for the balance of the year if you sort of look at the effective yen?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we have -- well, at the beginning of the year always, when we give the coverage, we're about a 70-or-so percent. So clearly, there might be a moment, we're always hedging, as you remember, 12 to 18 months ahead. So it's not 100% of the yen positions
componenttext: Well, we have -- well, at the beginning of the year always, when we give the coverage, we're about a 70-or-so percent. So clearly, there might be a moment, we're always hedging, as you remember, 12 to 18 months ahead. So it's not 100% of the yen positions or cash flow, which are hedged for this year, but it's a very, very significant portion of the yen projected cash flows are hedged. Maybe what's going to help is some of the hedges are executed in the form of calls and put options, right, the color option strategy, which not necessarily have to have an impact if we see the development of the year -- of the yen going outside the bracket. And then the sum of that is done for the forwards, okay? Forwards, obviously, you can't walk away. But the color options you have some flexibility so you can take advantage of what is the spot rates can be.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, got it. And I guess, presumably, some of those strategies would benefit as you move into the first part of 2016 as the hedges fall off.
componenttext: Okay, got it. And I guess, presumably, some of those strategies would benefit as you move into the first part of 2016 as the hedges fall off.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. As I said, I mean, because we always look 12 to 18 months ahead, there was already some portion of the 2017 expected cash flows from Japan in the yen, which are hedged. But obviously, they hedge also at the rate which are more corresponding to the --
componenttext: Yes. As I said, I mean, because we always look 12 to 18 months ahead, there was already some portion of the 2017 expected cash flows from Japan in the yen, which are hedged. But obviously, they hedge also at the rate which are more corresponding to the -- some of them to the more recent relative strengthening of the yen.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Growe with Stifel.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Chris Growe with Stifel.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I just have 2 questions for you, a bit of a follow-up to some earlier questions. I want to ask first, if I could, when I look at the price realization in Asia, there was a larger effect from the Korea price benefit a year ago than I thought. I guess it do
componenttext: I just have 2 questions for you, a bit of a follow-up to some earlier questions. I want to ask first, if I could, when I look at the price realization in Asia, there was a larger effect from the Korea price benefit a year ago than I thought. I guess it doesn't just of there is even stronger pricing in the Asia region then when I had modeled, given that was positive in the quarter. I guess, I just want to understand that the comparison factor on pricing was obviously was one of the major drags on Asia. That should help to better pricing in Q2 going forward based on what know today. Is that a reasonable assumption? .

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: It's a very reasonable assumption. We will still have a small relative to the first quarter, a small drag from Korea, but relatively not smaller than what we had in the first quarter. But the pricing in Asia in the quarter, okay, obviously, masked by the
componenttext: It's a very reasonable assumption. We will still have a small relative to the first quarter, a small drag from Korea, but relatively not smaller than what we had in the first quarter. But the pricing in Asia in the quarter, okay, obviously, masked by the Korea, but we have a very strong pricing in Indonesia. We had a pricing in Philippines, and we had the pricing in a few other locations. So overall, I mean, Asia should be in a much better pricing level or price realizations level than what you just saw in the Q1.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure. Let me confirm that. And then the other question I had was just in relation to the development of iQOS. And you had this very strong development in Japan but a slower development in countries like Italy or Switzerland, where it's been around about t
componenttext: Sure. Let me confirm that. And then the other question I had was just in relation to the development of iQOS. And you had this very strong development in Japan but a slower development in countries like Italy or Switzerland, where it's been around about the same amount of time. And you talked about some couple of the undertakings by the company to enhance the development of iQOS in Italy or Switzerland. I just want to understand them is that about 20 more money for creative and more embassies or stores in those markets, just what you're doing to try and boost the national expansion, if you will, and the adoption of the product in markets where it just isn't developed the same rate as Japan?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think we need to adjust for the marketing and the overall commercial environment, which we have in Japan versus what we've had in Switzerland or Italy or many other places. And this is -- covers the trade channels, what I call the route to the consumer
componenttext: I think we need to adjust for the marketing and the overall commercial environment, which we have in Japan versus what we've had in Switzerland or Italy or many other places. And this is -- covers the trade channels, what I call the route to the consumer to the trade, et cetera. So I think we're adjusting this one and trying to figure it out such a composition of all available to our blogs, which will result with manageable level of spending, if you like, versus the conversions rate, which we can achieve. Now Italy is -- I think we're going to track the Italy also this year. I remain very positive on this. Despite the fact that for the couple of quarters growth, we're talking about the 0.2% market share. I mean, that's not much of an issue, I think, frankly speaking, at this stage. If I look at what we have achieved and achieving in part of Switzerland, and as you noticed, we, in some places, going deliberately, very focused in order to nail down the model properly on the smaller territory. And then we feel comfortable, we explore. I mean, let me remind you. I mean, we had, as you remember, the market shares, conversions rates, which we had at Nagoya at the time of the city test, right, of the test market. No one, if you look at the progression of the share development in Nagoya, you wouldn't figure it out if we can accelerate the conversions and the market share to the levels that we have in a 60% of Japan, including Tokyo and other main cities. So I think we're trying to get comfortable and the smaller territory, that we know that we can amplify and explore and amplify the right components of our marketing mix, broadly marketing mix. And then we go to the national level. And it's actually -- it's a part of, obviously, higher cost spend, higher investment more prudently invested into something, which really gives you a proper result. So -- and I am excited about the Japan. I'm very excited about the Switzerland. And I'm sure, we're going to demonstrate later on this year what we can do in Italy as well.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016

componenttext: Our final question comes from the line of Adam Spielman with city.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just want to come back to the question about what's driving the much better historical volumes in the European Union. And you've obviously mentioned 4 factors. But I'm just wondering, and I know you said it's really impossible or hard to quantify the impa
componenttext: Just want to come back to the question about what's driving the much better historical volumes in the European Union. And you've obviously mentioned 4 factors. But I'm just wondering, and I know you said it's really impossible or hard to quantify the impact of migration. But I guess, what I'm trying to ask is what the evidence is, how good the evidence is of the impact from reduced illicit and whether -- and what sort of evidence you have, and whether you can quantify this in any way and also quantify the impact of reduced headwind from e-vapor.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we think we get a better reading at the market or the total region level when it comes to the illicit trade. I mean, obviously, there's always an estimate, but because the methodologies equally applied from year-on-year, I think we have a better acc
componenttext: Well, we think we get a better reading at the market or the total region level when it comes to the illicit trade. I mean, obviously, there's always an estimate, but because the methodologies equally applied from year-on-year, I think we have a better account for about saying that there is a recent contributions of the illicit trade. And the contributions goes, I guess, depends now versus one what period, you're talking about a few couple of points of the growth is coming from the illicit trade. Now you would have to resume into Germany, which presumably has a much larger impact than, for example, U.K. when the illicit trade is still on the growth. Italy had a good results. And the Southern Europe actually is doing better. As you know, the recent moves also over last few months have found reinforcing, the border controls are reintroducing actually the border controls in between there, some EU states, EU markets and also outside. I mean, there clearly are another factor we feel contributes to tightening the domestic taxpaid market. I always give example of Turkey, which I know is outside EU. But Turkey has reduced the illicit trade year-on-year by about 10, 11 points, which is about half. I mean, the Turkish market normally wouldn't be growing -- or Turkish consumption, if you like, wouldn't be growing by a 10% or 11%. We're talking about the industry tax paid volumes growing for this magnitude. And this is clearly the recovery coming from a 10, 11 points almost of the recovery from the illicit trade. So I guess, you'll see the correlations. And that's -- I said to one of the questions earlier, it's more comfortable for us to talk about the illicit trade because there's quite a lot of data available or estimate available, and you can deduct for the high dose of a probability that this is a contributing factor. Immigrations more something which we hear about from -- read in the newspaper, et cetera. Clearly, this is -- there are movements in the dislocation of population, immigrations, et cetera, in some places. I think they do have a factor. They do have an impact on the industry.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And e-vapor?
componenttext: And e-vapor?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q1 2016 Earnings Call, Apr 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: And E-vapor, well, if you look at where the product was in some places like Italy, for example, a year or so ago and how much was the trial, which at least temporary to consumers from a conventional cigarette, and where this products are today, I mean, cr
componenttext: And E-vapor, well, if you look at where the product was in some places like Italy, for example, a year or so ago and how much was the trial, which at least temporary to consumers from a conventional cigarette, and where this products are today, I mean, cruising somewhere at 1% or below even 1% market share in the most of the places. I mean, clearly, those consumers get back to the conventional cigarettes. So you could have this -- again, you would have to grow into markets by market basis. What is happening, as you know, the e-cigarettes category does not attract a lot of loyalty to the category itself. There's a lot of dual usage, dual consumption most of the time, so far, leading to consumer turning back to e-cigarette then and coming back to the conventional product.
