And when we look at the impact of a few large excise tax increases like Argentina and Algeria, has the excise environment in any way shifted or become more challenging?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: First, on the volume. Look, I think at this stage, I think we'll prefer to say that we will likely miss our volume high expectations, our initial expectations for the year. I think we'll come definitely lower than 1.5% decline, which are 1% to 1.5% declin
componenttext: First, on the volume. Look, I think at this stage, I think we'll prefer to say that we will likely miss our volume high expectations, our initial expectations for the year. I think we'll come definitely lower than 1.5% decline, which are 1% to 1.5% decline. We might be as low as 3% for the full year. This will be coming from the few geographies which not necessarily put a big pressure on our bottom line, but that's -- at this stage, that might be the outlook for the full year. This obviously may result in some industry volumes to be adjusted accordingly. I think initially, we said that industry somewhere should be in the range of 2% to 2.5% and industry might be lower by 2.5%. But we will have to see, okay? Just to be on a cautious side. Now when it comes to tax increases, yes, Argentina was a very large increase and resulted in a very high price increase. So there is, I think, at this moment, we could see impact on the volume. And I think it may continue for some time, maybe not for the long time because this outsized tax increase happens in the high inflationary markets. I guess that time will help the consumers to accommodate to the price level, I would argue, faster than in our situation. And outside Argentina, frankly speaking, we have not had anything which will be very disturbing on excise increase. I mean, Algeria, it's much more -- the whole context of the North Africa, the political instability, what is happening at the borders in the individual markets, countries there. Plus we have a specific, to us, issue, which I highlighted in my remarks, connected with the rollout of Architecture 2.0 for the Marlboro Red variant when we had, I have to admit, the first market in which we've been confronted with the less or lower-than-expected acceptance of a new Marlboro. And as you know, we have rolled out Marlboro to 100-plus markets. And this is the only market in which we had some significant headwinds from the beginning of the year. We're obviously working on addressing that thing. It's a marketing perception program. But it may take us some time to address this. So hopefully, part of that improvement we should see already this year. I hope I answered your questions.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sure, yes. As far as the EPS guidance, you reiterated 10% to 12%, but it seems like it's going to be around 2% through the first 9 months. So that, just based on rough numbers, suggests about 50% growth in Q4 and basically would imply maybe that the margi
componenttext: Sure, yes. As far as the EPS guidance, you reiterated 10% to 12%, but it seems like it's going to be around 2% through the first 9 months. So that, just based on rough numbers, suggests about 50% growth in Q4 and basically would imply maybe that the margins are similar throughout the year rather than stepping down in Q4. So I guess, mechanically, I can see how it works. But the comparison to last year's elevated spending in the fourth quarter seemed to be about a 3% to 4% tailwind for the full year. So in terms of closing the gap and getting up to that 10% to 12% range, are there any other specific factors or sources of flexibility around the timing of reinvestment that you can point to just to sort of increase our confidence around the levers you have to pull to get up to that level of earnings growth?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, for the full year, we said that our total cost of conventional combustible cigarettes and RRPs will not be higher than 1%, excluding currency, full year 2016 versus full year 2015. Now part of this cost and the timing of these cost increases year-on
componenttext: Look, for the full year, we said that our total cost of conventional combustible cigarettes and RRPs will not be higher than 1%, excluding currency, full year 2016 versus full year 2015. Now part of this cost and the timing of these cost increases year-on-year are more in the beginning of the year rather than the second half of the year. So when we enter into Q3 but Q4 very much, we really will have very favorable comparisons, not only on the cost line, also on the revenue. I just want to remind that remember the number presumably very well, where the EPS, minus almost 4% in the Q4 last year. So clearly, we'll come very strong -- with a very strong growth this year. And it just happened that this is a phasing and a timing of the quarters, partially the comp, partially the events of the current year, how we're going to make it. Look, we're very confident of achieving 10% to 12%. But do understand that the pacing of the quarter is not maybe ideal, but the year has 4 quarters and we're working on delivering the 10% to 12% EPS growth ex currency.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Bonnie Herzog of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Bonnie Herzog of Wells Fargo.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to circle back with a quick question on the volume deceleration you mentioned in the year. You are now expecting shipment volume to be worse than you originally anticipated. So I guess I'm curious to hear from you, what is offsetting the weaker v
componenttext: I wanted to circle back with a quick question on the volume deceleration you mentioned in the year. You are now expecting shipment volume to be worse than you originally anticipated. So I guess I'm curious to hear from you, what is offsetting the weaker volume to give you the confidence to maintain your currency-neutral EPS guidance of 10% to 12%? And should we assume growth will be closer to the lower end of that range, given the weaker volume?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Look, it's a good question. Thank you because actually, it reminded me that I forgot to put it in the context of iQOS, right, that the volumes, which we -- that the guidance or the expectations for the volume which we shared are obviously on the combustib
componenttext: Look, it's a good question. Thank you because actually, it reminded me that I forgot to put it in the context of iQOS, right, that the volumes, which we -- that the guidance or the expectations for the volume which we shared are obviously on the combustible cigarettes. And as you noticed presumably on the quarter already, we start having quite significant volumes of iQOS, which are not included in this number. Now clearly, iQOS sales or HeatSticks sales for the year will, to some extent, offset the volume declines, which we'll have on a combustible business. That, on a positive side, will not fully offset because we have capacity limitations, which I may -- on the HeatSticks, which I may cover in a second. Having said so, I mean, some of the volumes which may come short this year, they're coming from the relatively lower-margin places, except for Algeria, where we have a problem with Marlboro. I mean, the Pakistan volumes, the Philippines volumes, they count in the statistics, if you like, but they don't really make a big impact or big change at the bottom line. So we're pretty comfortable, especially Philippines because the market is losing and we're losing the extremely low-margin volumes or 0 margin volumes at the bottom of the market and we're having some positive recovery for the mix for Marlboro. Now coming to iQOS is that, as you might have noticed, the shipments for the total of PMI of iQOS in a quarter to $1.6 billion, they're almost 4x higher than what we had in the first quarter. So we can see the dynamics of the acceptance of iQOS. Obviously, it's very much driven by Japan, and we have to be very much focused on Japan this year because we don't have unlimited capacity. You might remember, we have accelerated the launch plans of all markets, including Japan, by about a year, not being fully ready on the manufacturing side. Initially, our capacity was to be in the range of 5 billion units. We have made some efforts to increase that capacity by 1 billion or so this year. But I wouldn't expect any further miracles on our capacity this year. And we may continue with some pressure on our capacity for the beginning of this year. We're right now revising our CapEx plans and in order to accelerate not only the increase or the acceleration of the 30 billion capacity plant, which we built in Italy, in order to be able to satisfy the market demand.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And I actually did want to ask you also about what you're seeing in Japan with iQOS. You called out in the press release your combustible cig share in Japan was 25.8%, and then for iQOS, or HeatSticks, I should say, 2.2%. And you not
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And I actually did want to ask you also about what you're seeing in Japan with iQOS. You called out in the press release your combustible cig share in Japan was 25.8%, and then for iQOS, or HeatSticks, I should say, 2.2%. And you noted that your combined national share in Japan is 27.5%, which is a nice share gain of over 2 share points versus the year-ago period. So I was hoping you could talk about the rate of cannibalization from iQOS that you're seeing. It seems maybe low. And are you seeing lower cannibalization in Japan, for instance, versus other markets? I'd just love to hear sort of the differences in cannibalization rates by market.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: We do, indeed, see a better cannibalization, i.e., lower cannibalization rate, in Japan now as we had 6 or so months ago. So I have the numbers. I mentioned the numbers in my remarks. I mean, that's a pretty nice improvement. And we see the same in other
componenttext: We do, indeed, see a better cannibalization, i.e., lower cannibalization rate, in Japan now as we had 6 or so months ago. So I have the numbers. I mentioned the numbers in my remarks. I mean, that's a pretty nice improvement. And we see the same in other places, okay, in other markets outside Japan, although obviously, we're in a much more focused, smaller territories, et cetera. Now Japan's share, which we have disclosed today, allowed us to leave the total corporate share, i.e., for both combined categories, by more than 2 points. So I think that's significant, especially in Japan. Now what's more important is if we look at the exit shares of June, so you might think the last week, last 2 weeks, how it's been accruing in Japan, we have crossed the 5 points, 5% share of market mark in Tokyo, okay? And we're still growing. I mean, the volume growth is somewhere in the range of about 20-plus percent on a monthly basis. So we could see the push. We could see the consumers coming to iQOS stores and to other places in which devices are available almost fully prepared, fully, one could say, converted already to the use of iQOS as the conversion rate are double of what we had at the beginning of our iQOS journey in Japan. We estimate, Bonnie, that at this point in time, we might have about 600,000 exclusive or fully switched users of iQOS in Japan. It essentially translates with the 600,000 people in Japan who quit combustible smoking, and they fully adopted iQOS. I think it's spectacular.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, that's great to hear. And just one final question, if I may, on your margins. Your operating margins were down 200 bps in the quarter. So I guess I'm trying to understand what some of the key drivers of the margin contraction were. Also curious to und
componenttext: No, that's great to hear. And just one final question, if I may, on your margins. Your operating margins were down 200 bps in the quarter. So I guess I'm trying to understand what some of the key drivers of the margin contraction were. Also curious to understand why margins were down this much, considering your volume declines that you mentioned in the quarter were really mainly in the low-margin geographies. So I guess I would have assumed you would have had a little bit more of a positive mix there.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think the inventory comps, which we had, and the shipment-driven comps, which we have in Japan, were very much behind the PMI and the Asia margins. I mean, you're talking about 1.9 billion difference in the shipments in Japan on the conventional cigaret
componenttext: I think the inventory comps, which we had, and the shipment-driven comps, which we have in Japan, were very much behind the PMI and the Asia margins. I mean, you're talking about 1.9 billion difference in the shipments in Japan on the conventional cigarettes -- on the combustible cigarettes. And this would clearly give you the impact just from that, in the north of $70 million. So I think that is we've been missing. We have -- the way we look at this thing also is are we lifting the margins Q2 to Q1 because we ended up Q1 with not-so-great margins. And I think sequentially, we're going up and I think we will have more of the margin improvement for year when the pricing realization is getting usually stronger in a number of places. We have a much better situation with the pricing in Ukraine, which eroded a lot of other margins in Q1, a bit less or much less in Q2. And I think the things are going in the right direction. And as I said, I mean, some of the volume headwinds which we have going forward, except for Algeria, they're not really coming from high unit margin countries.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Judy Hong of Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Judy Hong of Goldman Sachs.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Jacek, I wanted to ask about pricing. In 2Q, your pricing variance of $344 million is still tracking a bit below kind of the full year run rate. So I know you called out a couple of factors, but maybe if you can just quantify the key drivers. And then it
componenttext: Jacek, I wanted to ask about pricing. In 2Q, your pricing variance of $344 million is still tracking a bit below kind of the full year run rate. So I know you called out a couple of factors, but maybe if you can just quantify the key drivers. And then it sounds like you're still expecting a 6% pricing variance for the full year, which implies a big acceleration in the back half. So just wanted to get your comfort level around that. And then related to that, you also called out some increased promotional support on iQOS. It sounds like, in Japan, that kind of hurt pricing. So maybe you can give us some more color on that as well.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. I think the first half of the year, Q1, a bit of Q2, is still impacted by Korea, right? So the price realization obviously looks at the lower level due to the comps. Thus, we had quite a significant price reductions in Ukraine at the beginning of th
componenttext: Okay. I think the first half of the year, Q1, a bit of Q2, is still impacted by Korea, right? So the price realization obviously looks at the lower level due to the comps. Thus, we had quite a significant price reductions in Ukraine at the beginning of the year, which I just mentioned a moment ago, we said a phasing-out. And the situation is improving. So Korea impacting the outer quarters is no longer there. Negative drag is no longer there. Ukraine should get better plus we have a pricing which was taking in a quarter. So I think we'll have more of the realizations. Indonesia always plays the significant role because beginning of the year, they're not really in the net price increases, and now they're moving into the positive price territories. So I think the 6% is achievable. I think we feel confident about this. There is a pricing -- some price negativity due to the allowances of discounts, which we're giving to the iQOS purchasers, not the HeatSticks buyers, the iQOS purchasers in Japan. And although over a period of time, we'll have reduced in yen per device the discount due to the higher volume of the devices which we're selling, I mean, that puts a little bit of a negative on a pricing variance due to the allowances behind iQOS. But on the other hand, you always presell devices first, and then the HeatSticks with this adoption rate are following very soon. And the HeatSticks actually are bringing the whole margin to the business. I think that's on a positive side.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then I was hoping to get a little bit more color on Russia. I think your industry volume forecast is now a little bit better, down 7% for the full year. But it seems like your market share trends have worsened, particularly in ki
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then I was hoping to get a little bit more color on Russia. I think your industry volume forecast is now a little bit better, down 7% for the full year. But it seems like your market share trends have worsened, particularly in kind of the low to mid-priced brands. So when you compare the situation this year versus last year, where you're actually gaining share, what sort of changed in terms of the market share performance? Is it kind of your decision to not be as aggressive in the low to mid-priced brands from a pricing perspective? Has the competitive landscape gotten worse? So just a color on Russia.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, I think from the beginning of the year, we observed a bit lower or slower price implementation from competition. So yes, I mean, I think I have said already in Q1 that we might feel some sudden pressure in Russia. We'll just stick to our plan. We targ
componenttext: No, I think from the beginning of the year, we observed a bit lower or slower price implementation from competition. So yes, I mean, I think I have said already in Q1 that we might feel some sudden pressure in Russia. We'll just stick to our plan. We target double-digit OCI growth. And I think we can deliver on that. I mean, a part of this share price raise is literally the timing of the price implementation. So I don't think there was anything fundamentally broken with the brands, just the temporary opening of the price gaps in the markets. I wouldn't be too much worried about this. On the positive side, I mean, you remember initially, we thought that the market with this pricing in mind should stay about 9-or-so percent decline. It seems that the elasticity continues to be on the more positive side for us. So I think 7% is the recent outlook for the industry volume, so I think we should be okay. Also important is that we see a guidance-to-guidance improvement of global exchange rates. So I think that the whole pressure on the Russian economy is a little bit less, which is improving a bit than initially we thought.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So just if I can clarify, the pricing -- the timing of the price increases and the competitive actions, are at this point all of your competitors now in line with your pricing?
componenttext: Okay. So just if I can clarify, the pricing -- the timing of the price increases and the competitive actions, are at this point all of your competitors now in line with your pricing?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: They're all in line with the pricing. But if I would give, for example, 80%, the price implementation, coverage of the product with the new price in every retail outlet in Russia, competitions might be at the 60% or 50%. They're just rolling up the prices
componenttext: They're all in line with the pricing. But if I would give, for example, 80%, the price implementation, coverage of the product with the new price in every retail outlet in Russia, competitions might be at the 60% or 50%. They're just rolling up the prices. The price increase does not, Judy, happen at 1 day in all outlets, okay? You're shipping the old product, new product, more of the new product, the new priced product. This is a typical price implementation in Russia and actually in many other places as well. So we just see that the prices which they're implementing in the market are in line with, we feel, like our pricing. It's just they have less of the distribution, if you like, of their products at the new prices than us in a given moment in time. So obviously, in this outlet, when the price gaps is opening, at least temporarily some of our brands might feel pressure.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's clear. And then my last question, just quickly on currency. So on the yen, obviously it's been a favorable move in the last few months. So I wanted to just get an update on your hedged position on the yen, how much your cover for this year an
componenttext: Okay, that's clear. And then my last question, just quickly on currency. So on the yen, obviously it's been a favorable move in the last few months. So I wanted to just get an update on your hedged position on the yen, how much your cover for this year and what's the effective hedge rate is for this year.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, with the forecasted cash flows, et cetera, from Japan for this year, we are about 70% hedged. And I think it was the first quarter in a long time when effective rate of the yen this quarter was by a bit but better than the effective rate of the yen
componenttext: Well, with the forecasted cash flows, et cetera, from Japan for this year, we are about 70% hedged. And I think it was the first quarter in a long time when effective rate of the yen this quarter was by a bit but better than the effective rate of the yen the same quarter last year. So we're essentially moving the yen into positive territory.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Vivien Azer of Cowen and Company.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Vivien Azer of Cowen and Company.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: So just wanted to follow up on iQOS. Sorry to belabor the point, but certainly your results are very encouraging. As we think about the outsized demand that you're seeing in Japan, how has that influenced your outlook for spend more broadly in the 20 mark
componenttext: So just wanted to follow up on iQOS. Sorry to belabor the point, but certainly your results are very encouraging. As we think about the outsized demand that you're seeing in Japan, how has that influenced your outlook for spend more broadly in the 20 markets that you're targeting?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we're still aiming at commercializing iQOS in the 20 cities, markets by the year-end. Obviously, as I mentioned earlier, I mean, we have to bear in mind that we don't have fully available capacity. And we are today in a situation that we have a nati
componenttext: Well, we're still aiming at commercializing iQOS in the 20 cities, markets by the year-end. Obviously, as I mentioned earlier, I mean, we have to bear in mind that we don't have fully available capacity. And we are today in a situation that we have a national coverage -- the only place where we have a national coverage is Japan. And we know that those will switch to iQOS. So 600,000-plus consumers in Japan, we cannot put them in a situation of out of stock because they themselves told us that after 2 or 3 weeks of smoking iQOS, they actually don't want to, don't like to and they cannot switch back to cigarettes. So we're a little bit trapped now in this situation that we have to make sure that Japan has a continuity of the supply before we start to put foot stronger on the pedal in other places. So we're preparing our iQOS stores. I think, by now, we have more than 20 flagship stores in a number of geographies, obviously including Japan. We're preparing the Internet. We're preparing the sales force, the whole commercializations, we can start. We're recruiting the first consumers, the first smokers in these places. But frankly speaking, at this stage, throwing more resources would just generate a higher demand. And we are not in a situation where we can meet the demand with our supply constraints at this moment in time. So this is how we have to work. The second market which is close to national expansion, full expansion, is Switzerland. And in Switzerland, we start moving -- if you remember the market share in the German part. And I think we grew the volumes in that part by about 50% quarter-on-quarter. We continue growing the market share in the French part. We think we crossed about the 2% market share at the end of Q2. So it's not in our interest now, knowing that we don't have a continuity of supply at this moment, to push the march on iQOS.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful. And just to follow up on that, when you're referring to kind of national distribution, should I understand that to mean that you've got kind of 100% of your targeted retail penetration in a market like Japan or you're getting close to
componenttext: That's very helpful. And just to follow up on that, when you're referring to kind of national distribution, should I understand that to mean that you've got kind of 100% of your targeted retail penetration in a market like Japan or you're getting close to that in Switzerland? Are there more stores that you want to enter?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Japan, I guess, is fully covered now. I mean, there may be few outlets, okay? We have some limitations on the device sales because the only way we can manage the constraints on the HeatStick capacity is to limit the iQOS device sales. And actually, to be
componenttext: Japan, I guess, is fully covered now. I mean, there may be few outlets, okay? We have some limitations on the device sales because the only way we can manage the constraints on the HeatStick capacity is to limit the iQOS device sales. And actually, to be frank, in all outlets in Japan, key accounts, general trades, et cetera, they're at the purchase limit per store. And I think we're shipping the product only twice a week with very limited quantities in order to stop or slow down the conversion because it will result in a higher demand for the HeatSticks. And the HeatStick is the bottleneck which we have for now. And the same applies, to a large extent, to other places. Now if I compare Switzerland, I think iQOS is now available in 200-plus outlets. So we're not really in the full national coverage in any of these places. Moscow, we're in a couple of stores. We have one store in Lisbon. So it's really very small. But if I look at the volume trends, which if you might remember from my presentation a few minutes ago, the volume trends are extremely encouraging. I mean, you have a truly exponential growth.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Lavery of CLSA.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Lavery of CLSA.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just going back to currency. I know it's early to look ahead to next year. But in our numbers, it looks like you've actually got a slight tailwind, which, of course, we haven't really talked about for a long time. Just very roughly, does that seem accurat
componenttext: Just going back to currency. I know it's early to look ahead to next year. But in our numbers, it looks like you've actually got a slight tailwind, which, of course, we haven't really talked about for a long time. Just very roughly, does that seem accurate? And I guess related to that, can you just remind us some of your thinking about if and when you could consider resuming buyback?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, Michael, look, I wish I knew where the currency is going to be next year. But let me put that right. We had a headwind on the currency for the last 3 years. So I think it would be very fair if some of this headwind converts into tailwind to us. Now
componenttext: Well, Michael, look, I wish I knew where the currency is going to be next year. But let me put that right. We had a headwind on the currency for the last 3 years. So I think it would be very fair if some of this headwind converts into tailwind to us. Now once we have a strong tailwind on the currency, I think we might be then only in the situations to reconsider the buyback.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Would it be fair to say that you want to be careful so that you don't resume buybacks just to have to spend them again? Is that part of how you think about it?
componenttext: Would it be fair to say that you want to be careful so that you don't resume buybacks just to have to spend them again? Is that part of how you think about it?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we'd rather -- I think if we were to raise the buyback, we would like to see the positive outlook for the next few years, so have something of the, I guess, more longer-lasting program than just 1 quarter or 1 year with the buyback. Remember, our fo
componenttext: Well, we'd rather -- I think if we were to raise the buyback, we would like to see the positive outlook for the next few years, so have something of the, I guess, more longer-lasting program than just 1 quarter or 1 year with the buyback. Remember, our focus always more strategically is on the dividend and creating the room for the dividend growth. And buyback comes -- after all our opportunities to invest, I mean, buyback will come last.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, that's helpful. And then back on iQOS. Can you remind us when full capacity comes online? I think you've said it was the end of this year. But how specific can you be? And then related to that, you have acceleration in, it looks like, every market, es
componenttext: No, that's helpful. And then back on iQOS. Can you remind us when full capacity comes online? I think you've said it was the end of this year. But how specific can you be? And then related to that, you have acceleration in, it looks like, every market, especially Japan, which is the biggest. If that continues, is it possible you might need to postpone the other 10 markets that you expect to launch in this year just to be able to keep servicing the ones where you're already present?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the other markets which we have in the plan for this year is that we're, I think, postponing the market. We'll delay the entire commercializations. And we know that as of Q1, Q2, latest next year, based on our sales forecast obviously, we should be
componenttext: Well, the other markets which we have in the plan for this year is that we're, I think, postponing the market. We'll delay the entire commercializations. And we know that as of Q1, Q2, latest next year, based on our sales forecast obviously, we should be in a comfortable capacity territory. So I think we'd rather let the market grow as we had per plan. One iQOS store will not put that much of a stretch initially on our capacity. We're just very mindful in the developments in Japan because that's -- every few percentage error on the forecast which we have translates into tens or hundreds of millions of HeatSticks. And this is where the focus is for the time being. Capacity, the initial plan of the building the factory for 30 billion. We're actually accelerating the delivery of that capacity. And as I said, as of Q1, we should month-by-month see the progression in available capacity. But this is obviously confronted with a pretty steep growth curve which we have in Japan. So we have a little bit of a vicious cycle on the site. But we right now are also working on resolving that problem.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: But so just to clarify, I think you've got the 5 billion to 6 billion capacity out of Neuchâtel. The plant in Italy, when would that come online?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: We already started producing in Italy, okay? We're producing a little bit still in a development center in Neuchâtel in Switzerland. And this is mainly to keep demand satisfied in Switzerland. And at Bologna plant, both the training center and the new fa
componenttext: We already started producing in Italy, okay? We're producing a little bit still in a development center in Neuchâtel in Switzerland. And this is mainly to keep demand satisfied in Switzerland. And at Bologna plant, both the training center and the new factory, actually started producing the HeatSticks. And they're already shipping everything to Japan and a few other places. So this [indiscernible] factory from the structure perspective and infrastructure is ready. We're just in a phase of installing the machines. So there is a pace of installing the production line. And every month, we will be better with the capacity. But we cannot just install 30 billion in one go. 30 billion translates into x number of machine groups and one-by-one have to be installed, tested, and then moving through commercial production.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful color. And then just lastly on Italy, it looks like in your one slide, you've shown an acceleration in momentum there from the beginning of the year. Obviously, that's the market where there have been relatively little traction. How m
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful color. And then just lastly on Italy, it looks like in your one slide, you've shown an acceleration in momentum there from the beginning of the year. Obviously, that's the market where there have been relatively little traction. How much has that picked up? What kind of share are you seeing now? It seems, I'm guessing, still pretty small. But what have you seen made a difference that it's better than it was?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Because we see the higher conversion than we initially had. So Italy, like Japan, a month ago, started with a 30-or-so percent conversion. And I think Italy is approaching 70% conversion. So from every 100 devices which we sell, iQOS devices which we sell
componenttext: Because we see the higher conversion than we initially had. So Italy, like Japan, a month ago, started with a 30-or-so percent conversion. And I think Italy is approaching 70% conversion. So from every 100 devices which we sell, iQOS devices which we sell, 70 devices are in a permanent use, i.e., consumers fully switched to iQOS. And our share for total Italy is not a firm number because we're not really present in the whole Italy by taking the places where we are. And assuming that we properly can estimate an underlying market in these places, it's a little bit of science and art actually together, I think we're approaching about 0.3, maybe 0 -- about the 0.3% [ph] in the market share. So versus where we've been at the beginning, remember, Milan was, for the longest time, 0.1, 0.2. 0.2 to 0.3 is quite a significant improvement. If I take it from a volume perspective, I mean, we see in Italy, like in another places, about 20% volume growth every month, month-per-month. So we're starting on a slow pace, [indiscernible], but the growth is there. So I think the moment when we'll be able to amplify Italy to the national coverage, like we did in Japan, obviously we need to discount the different channels of communications which we have available in Italy versus in Japan. But I think the prospects are there. I think we should see more and more of Japan -- of the Italy improvements or strong performance towards -- in the second part of the year. And the term of the volume trend as of Q1, Q2, which you had on the slide in my part of the presentation, you just highlight that we start pushing the right buttons there.

componenttext: Just a quick one for me. Clearly, last month or so, we've had a number of geopolitical shocks. And I appreciate it's early days. But have you seen any signs in your categories in any of the affected markets that the consumer is in any way sort of changing their spending behavior?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q2 2016 Earnings Call, Jul 19, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, you have some down-trading in some places in the North Africa. Egypt, which has the macroeconomic situation, is challenging. And Egypt will remain on the watchlist for the remainder of the year. In Algeria, which on the one hand, is in our marketing
componenttext: Well, you have some down-trading in some places in the North Africa. Egypt, which has the macroeconomic situation, is challenging. And Egypt will remain on the watchlist for the remainder of the year. In Algeria, which on the one hand, is in our marketing of the Marlboro, but on the other hand, is a bit of a down-trading followed by the few steps of excise price increases. And so yes, I mean, the markets are a bit weaker. I mean, long term, I guess the region has a great potential. If economy is in the south directions rather than the north direction, I mean, it will put a pressure on the consumers.
