headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to the Philip Morris International Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is scheduled to last about 1 hour, including remarks by Philip Morris International management and the question-and-answer session. [Operato
componenttext:
Good day, and welcome to the Philip Morris International Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is scheduled to last about 1 hour, including remarks by Philip Morris International management and the question-and-answer session. [Operator Instructions]
I will now turn the call over to Mr. Nick Rolli, Vice President of Investor Relations and Financial Communications. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome, and thank you for joining us. Earlier today, we issued a press release containing detailed information on our 2016 third quarter results. You may access the release on our website at www.pmi.com or the PMI Investor Relations App.During our call
componenttext:
Welcome, and thank you for joining us. Earlier today, we issued a press release containing detailed information on our 2016 third quarter results. You may access the release on our website at www.pmi.com or the PMI Investor Relations App.
During our call today, we will be talking about results for the third quarter of 2016 and comparing them to the same period in 2015, unless otherwise stated. A glossary of terms, adjustments and other calculations as well as reconciliations to the most directly comparable U.S. GAAP measures are at the end of today's webcast slides, which are posted on our website.
Reduced-Risk Products, or RRPs, is the term we use to refer to products with the potential to reduce individual risk and population harm in comparison to smoking cigarette.
Today's remarks contain forward-looking statements and projections of future results, and I direct your attention to the forward-looking and cautionary statements disclosure in today's presentation and press release for a review of the various factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from projections or forward-looking statements.
Now my pleasure to introduce Jacek Olczak, our Chief Financial Officer. Jacek?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Nick, and welcome, ladies and gentlemen. Following the comprehensive business review that we provided during our recent Investor Day event, I will focus today on a brief summary of our 2016 full year outlook and third quarter results and highli
componenttext:
Thank you, Nick, and welcome, ladies and gentlemen. Following the comprehensive business review that we provided during our recent Investor Day event, I will focus today on a brief summary of our 2016 full year outlook and third quarter results and highlight some important developments in select geographies. A detailed discussion of our third quarter and year-to-date September results can be found in our earnings release.
Let me begin with our full year outlook. As announced this morning, we are reaffirming our 2016 reported diluted EPS guidance at prevailing exchange rates to be in a range of $4.53 to $4.58. Our guidance includes $0.35 of unfavorable currency and continues to represent a growth rate, excluding currency, of approximately 10.5% to 11.5% compared to our adjusted diluted EPS of $4.42 in 2015.
As a reminder, in the fourth quarter, we anticipate strong, currency-neutral net revenue growth, driven primarily by the annualization of price increases and the growth of RRPs. We also anticipate a favorable cost comparison, driven by the significant investments that we made in the fourth quarter of 2015 behind iQOS and our cigarette brand portfolio, including those related to the implementation of the EU Tobacco Products Directive.
Moving to our third quarter results. Net revenues and adjusted OCI increased by 3.6% and 4.3%, respectively, excluding currency, reflecting favorable pricing, partly offset by negative volume/mix, particularly in the EEMA region. Adjusted diluted EPS increased by 4%, excluding currency.
Our favorable pricing variance of $440 million in the third quarter was driven by positive contributions from all regions, notably EEMA. During the quarter, we announced or implemented price increases in a number of markets, including those shown on the slide, which should further support favorable pricing in the fourth quarter.
We recorded currency-neutral financial growth in the third quarter despite an organic cigarette shipment volume decline of 5.4%. The decrease was due mainly to lower cigarette industry volume in Argentina, Indonesia, the Philippines and Russia as well as lower cigarette market share, notably in North Africa, the Philippines and Russia, partly offset by market share growth in the EU region.
Year-to-date September, our cigarette shipment volume declined by 3.9%, consistent with the year-to-date August decrease that I referenced at Investor Day. We continue to anticipate a similar decline for the full year 2016.
Our shipment volume for heated tobacco sticks reached 2.1 billion units in the third quarter, an increase of approximately 900 million units compared to the second quarter of this year. While principally driven by Japan, all iQOS-launched markets contributed to this growth. While our cigarette market share, excluding China and the U.S., declined by 0.6 points in the third quarter due notably to North Africa, the Philippines and Russia, Marlboro cigarette share increased by 0.3 points, driven by the EU and Asia region.
Let me now move to select geographies, beginning with the EU region. Regional cigarette industry volume declined by 1.4% in the third quarter, contributing to a year-to-date September decrease of 0.2%. For the full year, we continue to expect a decline of around 1%. Our regional cigarette share in the quarter increased by 0.4 points, driven by the continued strong performance of Marlboro, which grew share in 4 of the region's top 6 markets by cigarette industry volume, notably Germany and Spain.
In Indonesia, we recorded sequential market share growth in the third quarter, driven by our strong performance in the full-flavor, machine-made kretek segment, notably following the geographical expansion of U Bold in June. To further enhance our position, in September, we launched Marlboro Filter Black kretek in 25 cities. Although it is early, we strongly believe that this offer will set the standard for the full-flavor, machine-made kretek segment.
In addition, this month, the Indonesian Ministry of Finance issued its 2017 excise tax regulation, which will result in a weighted average excise tax increase of approximately 10% industry-wide. As you may recall, the weighted average increase in 2016 was approximately 15%.
In Japan, our cigarette market share continued to stabilize and was essentially flat compared to the third quarter of last year. This performance is notable, given the impact of HeatSticks cannibalizations on our cigarette share and was supported by recent Lark and Marlboro launches.
IQOS continues to perform exceptionally well, with HeatSticks market share reaching 4.3% in the last week of September. In the third quarter, HeatSticks market share was 3.5%, an increase of 1.3 points compared to the second quarter of 2016. Importantly, the share gains have been achieved despite the limits we have placed on iQOS device sales since June.
PMI's total combined market share, including cigarettes and HeatSticks, was 27.9% in the third quarter, reflecting an increase of 2.5 points compared to the same period in 2015.
In North Africa, our third quarter market share was 24.6%, representing a sequential increase versus the second quarter. This growth was driven by the improving performance of Marlboro in Algeria, highlighting the early success of the initiatives that we shared during the Investor Day.
In Russia, the Ministry of Finance submitted a proposal earlier this month to raise the specific and the minimum excise tax levels for 2017 by approximately 10% above what is currently in the tax code. If the proposal is approved by the Duma and signed into law by the President, it will result, assuming full pass-on, in a total tax pass-on of approximately RUB 11 per pack in 2017. The ad valorem rate of 13% remains unchanged in the proposal.
I will finish my discussion of important developments with an update on the cigarette market in Argentina. While cigarette industry volume continues to be impacted by the significant excise tax-driven price increases in May, declining 14.1% in the third quarter, adult smokers appear to be adjusting relatively quickly to the higher retail prices, given the broader inflationary environment. The average monthly decline in August and September was 8%. We continue to expect a full year cigarette industry volume decline of around 12% in 2016 and a return to its low single-digit historical decline rate during 2017 once the May 2016 target increase has been lapped.
In conclusion, our third quarter results were in line with our expectations, and our full year outlook remains strong.
Thank you, and I will be happy now to answer your questions.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question is from the line of Michael Lavery with CLSA.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Could you just talk about Russia for a minute? You -- we've seen the consumer there been pretty resilient in the past. You're now calling out some share pressure from pricing ahead of competitors. Are you seeing a change in the consumer approach? And are
componenttext: Could you just talk about Russia for a minute? You -- we've seen the consumer there been pretty resilient in the past. You're now calling out some share pressure from pricing ahead of competitors. Are you seeing a change in the consumer approach? And are they -- is there any change in their willingness to spend? And especially, if so, could you give any sort of estimate of what you think the impact of the proposed tax increase might be as well?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I start with the last part. I mean, the impact, as I said, is about RUB 11 if passed on. So it's around the same level as we had last year. [indiscernible]
componenttext: I start with the last part. I mean, the impact, as I said, is about RUB 11 if passed on. So it's around the same level as we had last year. [indiscernible]

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Sorry. Could I clarify? I guess, I meant, with that increase, do you expect any different category impact this year versus last year -- next year versus this year?
componenttext: Sorry. Could I clarify? I guess, I meant, with that increase, do you expect any different category impact this year versus last year -- next year versus this year?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, not really. I guess this is sort of the same increase as we had last year. And there was this 1 percentage point change in ad valorem, but I don't think it's going to change the dynamics between the segments. What you see in Russia on the consumer lev
componenttext: No, not really. I guess this is sort of the same increase as we had last year. And there was this 1 percentage point change in ad valorem, but I don't think it's going to change the dynamics between the segments. What you see in Russia on the consumer level is, yes, I mean, the consumer is looking value -- is looking for value. No question about it. I mean, at the Premium segment, at least judged by the share of Marlboro and especially Parliament, I mean, that will hold pretty strong pretty well. There is a down-trading. We observe a down-trading in the market but more between the mid- and the value segments. So this is where the extra price promotions or delays in the price implementations are most frequent. We're also launching our own initiatives in these segments. So I guess, also the share pressure which we have in Russia this year, I think we should start being on a positive share territory in 2017.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then with respect to Japan, I know it's maybe too early for you even to know, but do you have a sense with the proposed indoor smoking ban, if that might apply to iQOS as well?
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then with respect to Japan, I know it's maybe too early for you even to know, but do you have a sense with the proposed indoor smoking ban, if that might apply to iQOS as well?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not at this level of detail, so we're not going into discussions. Well, I can say that we have a number of places in Japan where the existing smoking bans have been lifted due to the fact that iQOS is not a combustible product. Therefore, there is no burn
componenttext: Not at this level of detail, so we're not going into discussions. Well, I can say that we have a number of places in Japan where the existing smoking bans have been lifted due to the fact that iQOS is not a combustible product. Therefore, there is no burning, there is no smoke. So we'll have to see how it's going to evolve. But in a current environment with the restrictions for smoking, et cetera, as you notice, I mean, iQOS continues to gain the penetrations and the market share. So I don't think it's going to stall the growth prospects of iQOS in Japan.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Bonnie Herzog with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Bonnie Herzog with Wells Fargo.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question has to do with your volume. And I was just hoping you could drill down a little further on the declines in the quarter. And then what gives you the confidence that you're going to still be able to hit the down around 3.9% for the full ye
componenttext: My first question has to do with your volume. And I was just hoping you could drill down a little further on the declines in the quarter. And then what gives you the confidence that you're going to still be able to hit the down around 3.9% for the full year? And then curious to hear how that compares with your expectations for the industry volume for the full year.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't change -- we wouldn't change the expectations for the industry volumes, which we have shared during the Investors Day. I think the trends are pretty much null at this stage. I think there are some improvements will continue into 2017. Specifica
componenttext: I wouldn't change -- we wouldn't change the expectations for the industry volumes, which we have shared during the Investors Day. I think the trends are pretty much null at this stage. I think there are some improvements will continue into 2017. Specifically, to us, I think -- I start maybe with the Latin America and Argentina. I think the consumer is adjusting to the prices pretty fast relative, obviously, to the price increase. I think this high inflation environment somehow helps. So I think, sequentially, we should see some -- less of the pressure from the volumes coming from -- or declines coming from Argentina. Algeria, which created quite a pressure on our volumes, and Marlboro -- including Marlboro this year, I mean, we start seeing the first signs of a recovery. It's going to take a while, but at least on the trend line, we close the lowest point. So I think already in Q4 and going into 2017, I think the pressure from Algeria, North Africa should ease. Indonesia, I think the tax proposal which came from the Ministry of Finance is manageable. I mean, you're looking for the just tax pass-on of about, say, 10% versus the 15% increase, which was -- which took place this year. So I think that should be helpful. In addition to the fact that I think -- at least judging for the last few quarters' performance of our share there, I think we should have less, if at all, share losses in 2017 than this year and, hopefully, a bit of stronger market than we have had in Indonesia this year. Philippines is a completely different story because it's all questions, how much we manage our mix to the positive territory. And so far, we are very successful with up-trading the markets to Marlboro, which continues to grow, very strong growth. And actually, we would like to enjoy this momentum for a longer while even if there are some pressures on the total industry volumes coming from the lower parts of the market. I think we would be fine with this. Pakistan, which also put quite a dent on our volume this year, that's presumably the most difficult to predict sort of the market because the other forces, which obviously play a role there. I mean, the contraband, I think, recently had reached about 1/3 of the market. So the question is where is the level of separation? And that said, so we can expect the worse than this. But again, from a financial perspective, it doesn't have that much of the impact -- doesn't have that much of a financial impact. So -- and Russia, the tax increase is also pretty manageable on the high side but comparable like we had at this year. And as I said earlier, I think Russia should also turn the corner when it comes to share decline. So next year, I guess, on a similar sort of the market dynamics, we should have less of a volume leakage due to the negative share performance.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That was really helpful. I appreciate that. And then I do have another question, I guess, on your other brand volume, which was down considerably in the quarter. So I was hoping you could talk a little bit about your strategy with some of these bran
componenttext: Okay. That was really helpful. I appreciate that. And then I do have another question, I guess, on your other brand volume, which was down considerably in the quarter. So I was hoping you could talk a little bit about your strategy with some of these brands. You touched on how the greater -- remember, at the Investor Day, you touched on having a greater focus on a fewer number of brands going forward. So I guess I'm assuming that it's consistent with the sharper declines we've been seeing for some of the smaller brands. And I guess I was also hoping you could confirm that. Although these brands are declining rapidly, they're contributing nicely to margins as they're likely promoted less.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, these brands will, in most case, actually have pretty low margins. I mean, the 2 big brands, which are in other categories, will be Fortune and very much Jackpot in Philippines. So these are the brands which have a near 0 sort of the margin territory
componenttext: Yes, these brands will, in most case, actually have pretty low margins. I mean, the 2 big brands, which are in other categories, will be Fortune and very much Jackpot in Philippines. So these are the brands which have a near 0 sort of the margin territory, and a lot of consumers are going from these brands to Marlboro. So we actually, for the positive mix, are improving pretty fast our financial situation there, our financial results there. We will have also brands in Indonesia in some other category, which are not necessarily on the higher end of the margin spectrum. So I would rather say brand like a Jackpot in Philippines would presumably trade, so we are actually treating this more tactically. Fortune is a little bit different. It's a brand which we do manage and we stay focused. But we do also recognize that at least at this stage, Marlboro, due to the closure of the price gap, is a more attractive proposition for the consumer, and we're absolutely fine with that. And Indonesia, I mean, many of these local brands, the brands which we do support, but we also try to focus on this less dilutive to our margins.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then maybe my final question, Jacek. You guys definitely watched through iQOS a lot at your Investor Day, but could you possibly highlight a few possible updates in the last few months on the improvements you've seen with conversion and maybe ca
componenttext: Okay. And then maybe my final question, Jacek. You guys definitely watched through iQOS a lot at your Investor Day, but could you possibly highlight a few possible updates in the last few months on the improvements you've seen with conversion and maybe cannibalization rates?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Conversion, I don't think I have a fresher number than that we have shared at the Investor Day. I mean, maybe a few numbers which I still remember because some of these KPIs we're tracking even more frequently. I think at Tokyo, if you might remember, the
componenttext: Conversion, I don't think I have a fresher number than that we have shared at the Investor Day. I mean, maybe a few numbers which I still remember because some of these KPIs we're tracking even more frequently. I think at Tokyo, if you might remember, the Tokyo market share, offtake share, at the Investor Day, which we shared, was 7%. We now stand at 7.3%. So we continue the growth, and the same is for Japan. I think our national offtake share the last week of -- or third week of September, which we have shared in Investors Day, 5.2%, now turns to be 5.5%. Then you consider pretty rapid share advancements, you're talking 20, 30 basis points in a span of a couple of few weeks. I have the same in Italy when I think the share in Italy, the launch area of 60 basis points, 0.6%, and now I think we lifted this last week of -- sorry, third week of October, I think the rating would be 0.8%. Switzerland, we lifted from 0.4% to 0.5%. The penetration rate, the number of devices sold continues to grow. So I think geographies, from the top of my head, I mean, there is a continuous growth momentum, very much in line of what we have shared with the investors at Investors Day.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have 2 questions, please. The first one is on iQOS in Japan. Clearly, you've limited the expansion because of the supply constraints you have. I just wondered if you could give us an estimate of what proportion of consumers don't have access to the prod
componenttext: I have 2 questions, please. The first one is on iQOS in Japan. Clearly, you've limited the expansion because of the supply constraints you have. I just wondered if you could give us an estimate of what proportion of consumers don't have access to the product right now and whether the existing users' over-index just focus of a particular strength for taste of cigarettes. That's my first question.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: We see the less and less of the other proportional representation of former Marlboro smokers compared to the underlying share of Marlboro. So clearly, the iQOS is taking more a significant inroads into the competitive combustible portfolio. Now how much,
componenttext: We see the less and less of the other proportional representation of former Marlboro smokers compared to the underlying share of Marlboro. So clearly, the iQOS is taking more a significant inroads into the competitive combustible portfolio. Now how much, really, we have less unhappy consumers in Japan at this stage. I know that they are waiting list. I know that the consumers have to enroll by name on this list, but to be frank, I don't have a number at this stage. The number exists somewhere. But we clearly -- we see how much of that backlog is the like of [indiscernible] consumers will have the momentum [indiscernible], which we estimate to happen somewhere in the end of the Q1 next year when we'll be very comfortable with the HeatSticks supplies. But my gut feeling is we're now starting about a 5% or 10% sort of unsatisfied demand. I think the number is much higher than that.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then my second question, more of a modeling one, which is your associate minority line has moved quite a bit since Q2. I just wondered if the numbers we're looking at in Q3 we could consider as more normalized plus some of the changes you
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then my second question, more of a modeling one, which is your associate minority line has moved quite a bit since Q2. I just wondered if the numbers we're looking at in Q3 we could consider as more normalized plus some of the changes you've had in those areas.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think so. I mean, there might be some movement. I think Russia should be -- the Megapolis should be okay. I think maybe there's some movements in North Africa around some of the structures, which we have in Egypt. But I think we should be pretty much in
componenttext: I think so. I mean, there might be some movement. I think Russia should be -- the Megapolis should be okay. I think maybe there's some movements in North Africa around some of the structures, which we have in Egypt. But I think we should be pretty much in line of what we could expect there. There are some currency -- the currency movements might have an impact on this line. And as you know, we have some exposure in Egypt on the -- we have to take the dollar exposure in Egypt, and there are some limitations in availability on the dollars in a country. So we might have some distortions with these lines coming from North Africa, Egypt, as I mentioned.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Matthew Grainger with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is actually Pam Kaufman on for Matt. I just wanted to ask on pricing. It improved sequentially to about 6.5% but needs to accelerate further to reach your benchmark of 6% for the full year and presumably reach the -- help bridge the gap to strong fou
componenttext: This is actually Pam Kaufman on for Matt. I just wanted to ask on pricing. It improved sequentially to about 6.5% but needs to accelerate further to reach your benchmark of 6% for the full year and presumably reach the -- help bridge the gap to strong fourth quarter earnings growth. Can you review where you've seen incremental pricing recently that would allow you to deliver on this target for the full year?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: We should have in the Q4 of this year, the strongest pricing variance compared to all the quarters. I mean, we're looking in the -- well in the north of a $500 million pricing variance in the quarter. And actually, it might be even closer to $600 million.
componenttext: We should have in the Q4 of this year, the strongest pricing variance compared to all the quarters. I mean, we're looking in the -- well in the north of a $500 million pricing variance in the quarter. And actually, it might be even closer to $600 million. We should have -- all in all, in the fourth quarter, we should expect above the 10% uplift on the revenue quarter-on-quarter, okay, on an ex-currency basis. So as I said, this -- the growth in the fourth quarter, on the one hand, will be coming from the favorable comp, which we have on the costs, while we still continue spending, obviously, more behind an iQOS, but it is more on the combustible part of spending compared to the Q4 last year. But we also are looking into -- we expect to have quite a significant uplift in the net revenue and correspondingly contributions to the bottom line.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Judy Hong with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Judy Hong with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So my question is on, actually, the mix impact because in addition to pretty healthy pricing, it sounds like the third quarter also benefited from strong mix. So how much is this geographic mix impact? And then when you think about the impact on iQOS, eit
componenttext: So my question is on, actually, the mix impact because in addition to pretty healthy pricing, it sounds like the third quarter also benefited from strong mix. So how much is this geographic mix impact? And then when you think about the impact on iQOS, either on price/mix, is there a way to kind of quantify how that would have impacted either the price or mix?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: The rate -- I mean, EU is doing well. So obviously, due to the margin, geographical margin split, I mean, on a geographical basis, the mix is working in our favor. If you go into individual countries, the countries with the worst mix in the quarter were a
componenttext: The rate -- I mean, EU is doing well. So obviously, due to the margin, geographical margin split, I mean, on a geographical basis, the mix is working in our favor. If you go into individual countries, the countries with the worst mix in the quarter were actually Indonesia and, if I recall well, actually was U.K. But overall -- but that's essential. When it comes to iQOS, yes, obviously, they already start adding the support to the revenue growth, and it's going to be even stronger in the Q4 of this year already. I guess when we close the year, we will start talking more about the financial impact of iQOS at least on the revenue -- at the revenue level, but there is already some volume impact. You know that we have a capacity of about 7 billion available this year. We sold less than 4 billion. So I think we've been very transparent with one can expect from the volumes of iQOS in the fourth quarter, and that's going to help lifting the revenue growth quite a bit.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So if we think about it, I think iQOS added about 1% to your total volume. So the revenue impact would have been higher in the second quarter -- I'm so sorry, in the third quarter?
componenttext: Okay. So if we think about it, I think iQOS added about 1% to your total volume. So the revenue impact would have been higher in the second quarter -- I'm so sorry, in the third quarter?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the pricing is at the Marlboro level, as you remember. Plus remember, in the revenue line, we'll also have devices, right, because we're selling the devices as well. So you have an uplift from the volume at the Marlboro price in a given geography, p
componenttext: Well, the pricing is at the Marlboro level, as you remember. Plus remember, in the revenue line, we'll also have devices, right, because we're selling the devices as well. So you have an uplift from the volume at the Marlboro price in a given geography, plus, obviously, the taxes and also the price that which we have the volume -- that which we're selling the devices to consumers. So they both contribute to the revenue.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just in Japan, I mean, it seems like your obviously contribution from iQOS is still very strong, but your combustible share has also gotten better. So can you just walk through how sustainable that sort of scenario of actually seeing combus
componenttext: Okay. And then just in Japan, I mean, it seems like your obviously contribution from iQOS is still very strong, but your combustible share has also gotten better. So can you just walk through how sustainable that sort of scenario of actually seeing combustible improvement, plus the iQOS contribution? It sounds like maybe Japan, your volume would have been up high single digits, ex inventory, if you add the iQOS volume.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think if you will take the full year impact, I mean, iQOS, clearly, is already a significant contributor to the -- to our business there. And Look, I have to actually thank you for raising these questions because I should say how proud we are that
componenttext: Yes. I think if you will take the full year impact, I mean, iQOS, clearly, is already a significant contributor to the -- to our business there. And Look, I have to actually thank you for raising these questions because I should say how proud we are that in 1 year, we managed to sort out the share pressure on the conventional business in Japan despite the fact that part of that share we have to gain for the cannibalization to iQOS. And in addition, we're so successful with iQOS. So I think the market share -- the biggest dynamics now which you will have in a market, I guess, is the cannibalizations and the movement between a combustible category, including our own portfolio, and iQOS. But the share leakage which we have to other pay segments and new pay segments, I mean, it seems at this stage that we have very successful [indiscernible]. So it's pretty, pretty remarkable result actually for our Japanese organization.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just finally, on currency. I know at the Investor Day, you talked about currency in '17 being less of a headwind versus '16. But just if we kind of pool spot rates at these levels, is there any kind of guidance you can give, a little bit mo
componenttext: Okay. And then just finally, on currency. I know at the Investor Day, you talked about currency in '17 being less of a headwind versus '16. But just if we kind of pool spot rates at these levels, is there any kind of guidance you can give, a little bit more specific guidance in '17, particularly around the yen, just given your hedge strategy?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I guess 2 questions, actually -- sorry, 2 facts, which would help maybe better predict the currency on your side of ocean on the rise of election, in fact, decision about the interest rates. So I am a little bit more remote from this one. I guess the
componenttext: Yes. I guess 2 questions, actually -- sorry, 2 facts, which would help maybe better predict the currency on your side of ocean on the rise of election, in fact, decision about the interest rates. So I am a little bit more remote from this one. I guess the number of currencies, if I look how currencies were playing against us this year -- and remember, we started the Q1 -- I guess we had like a $0.19. Q2, we were $0.08 on EPS. Q3, we're at $0.04. So clearly, we could see that the number of currencies have started to put a less pressure on us. Currency, which I singled out during the Investors Day, which many of us sometimes tend to forget, I mean, we have some exposures in North Africa, in particular, in Egypt. So the Egyptian pound is a little bit of the worry, and I don't know how they're going to relax the currency rules and how much it's going to translate into the devaluation. Other than that, ruble is prevailing pretty okay, euro, Japanese yen. Some that we hedge, we already hedged some positions in 2017. But the yen already started to contribute positively in the last few months, in the last quarter definitely. So we'll have to wait until February, post the elections, post the Fed decision. And presumably, this [indiscernible] unknown will be removed and we'll see how the market price the currencies a bit tight.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016

componenttext: I had just 2 questions, if I could. I want to ask, first of all, as you think about iQOS in Japan in particular and just given the constraints you have to your capacity right now, should we foresee further market share expansion in that market? Or are you kind of at a limit right now how much you can sell in that market incrementally?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we're still selling devices not to the level where there is a demand for the devices. As you know, we sell the device, you cannot trigger the consumption of HeatSticks. But we somehow manage the growth or we're limiting the growth to the correspondi
componenttext: Well, we're still selling devices not to the level where there is a demand for the devices. As you know, we sell the device, you cannot trigger the consumption of HeatSticks. But we somehow manage the growth or we're limiting the growth to the corresponding growth in the available production volume which we have, right? The capacity, which we have 7 billion this year, is not the 7 billion divided by 12 in equal installments per month, right? It very much is adding packs of -- the peak of January's capacity is going to be in the December this year. So yes, we can add some devices, but we're not satisfying the whole demand for the devices from the consumers. And this demand is [indiscernible] these newcomers, I mean, people who want to leave the combustible category, quit smoking, have now moved to iQOS, to heat-not-burn, but also existing consumers who want now second device, et cetera, because they -- for the convenience, whatever other purpose is, they want to have more devices. But we're selling more devices week-after-week, quarter-after-quarter, but not to the extent where the demand is for these devices in the market.

componenttext: I do not think a quarter is actually a good way of looking at things. There's always distortions. If I take 9 months this year, year-to-date, I think the total distortions, if I remember, in the tune of 200 million units by total volume. So it's a lot of things which will net over the period of time, the timing of the shipment, the inventories, et cetera. If I take Q3 on the year-to-date basis versus Q3 year-to-date basis last year, I think that the total -- due to the shipment -- timing of the shipment inventories will be above $200 million -- excuse me, 200 million units, 200 million units.

componenttext: I want to just -- I just want to be a little -- make sure that I've understood what's happening in the fourth quarter correctly. If I've understood it correctly, you said, first of all, there will be pricing variance of close to $600 million. And then on top of that, there will be benefits to -- from reduced costs, firstly, relating to the European Tobacco Products Directive; and secondly, less spending on Reduced-Risk Products. And then finally, and I'm just checking that I heard you correctly, your spending on conventional products will not change. Is that correct in the fourth quarter versus last year's fourth quarter?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016

componenttext: You're almost correct but not fully correct. So the pricing variance will be up to the $600 million -- $500 million plus up to $600 million. You'll have about $500 million or so in the comps. Not necessarily it means that the cost will get down, but in the comps, Q4 on a Q4, you will have in that $500 million higher spending on iQOS or RRPs but less spending in the quarter -- in that quarter on our combustibles. But I think for modeling purposes, I would just take you all have uplift in the revenue for the price and support of the volume coming from either some improved trends but very much for the iQOS and better comps on the cost Q4-on-Q4.

componenttext: No, but look, we have taken some costs ahead of the Tobacco Product Directive implementation or some related costs in a number of markets in the EU. We accelerated the spending in Q4 2015. And most of this initiative have already taken place. And in many countries, the Tobacco Product Directive now is in the physical product implementations in the sorts of all infrastructure, retooling machines and all the other associated costs have already been incurred. Therefore, optically, it looks like we have less spending on the combustibles in the Q4. But this is in the comparisons for Q4 last year.

componenttext: Okay. I think the release on the couple devices will happen towards the end of the Q1 next year [indiscernible] '17. Capacity, always 2 numbers to -- it's a pretty dynamic situation. There's 2 numbers to remember. You have available initial capacity this year of 7 billion, but in December, annualized, our capacity times 12 is 15 billion. If somebody wants to figure it out, what is my underlying capacity for the month of January, for example, the first month after December, it's 15 billion divided by 12. And then we add [indiscernible] in January, February and every month after that. So we'll have a commercial capacity for the full year of 2017 of 32 billion, hopefully a bit more than 32 billion. And we will close 2017, i.e. December, with 50 billion capacity. So if you take January 2018, my monthly capacity is 50 billion divided by 12, but also remember, then we'll be in the mode that we can add 4 billion capacity per month if needed, if we start to commit the capacity in the early part of 2017.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good day, and welcome to the Philip Morris International Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is scheduled to last about 1 hour, including remarks by Philip Morris International management and the question-and-answer session. [Operato
componenttext:
Good day, and welcome to the Philip Morris International Third Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. Today's call is scheduled to last about 1 hour, including remarks by Philip Morris International management and the question-and-answer session. [Operator Instructions]
I will now turn the call over to Mr. Nick Rolli, Vice President of Investor Relations and Financial Communications. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome, and thank you for joining us. Earlier today, we issued a press release containing detailed information on our 2016 third quarter results. You may access the release on our website at www.pmi.com or the PMI Investor Relations App.During our call
componenttext:
Welcome, and thank you for joining us. Earlier today, we issued a press release containing detailed information on our 2016 third quarter results. You may access the release on our website at www.pmi.com or the PMI Investor Relations App.
During our call today, we will be talking about results for the third quarter of 2016 and comparing them to the same period in 2015, unless otherwise stated. A glossary of terms, adjustments and other calculations as well as reconciliations to the most directly comparable U.S. GAAP measures are at the end of today's webcast slides, which are posted on our website.
Reduced-Risk Products, or RRPs, is the term we use to refer to products with the potential to reduce individual risk and population harm in comparison to smoking cigarette.
Today's remarks contain forward-looking statements and projections of future results, and I direct your attention to the forward-looking and cautionary statements disclosure in today's presentation and press release for a review of the various factors that could cause actual results to differ materially from projections or forward-looking statements.
Now my pleasure to introduce Jacek Olczak, our Chief Financial Officer. Jacek?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Nick, and welcome, ladies and gentlemen. Following the comprehensive business review that we provided during our recent Investor Day event, I will focus today on a brief summary of our 2016 full year outlook and third quarter results and highli
componenttext:
Thank you, Nick, and welcome, ladies and gentlemen. Following the comprehensive business review that we provided during our recent Investor Day event, I will focus today on a brief summary of our 2016 full year outlook and third quarter results and highlight some important developments in select geographies. A detailed discussion of our third quarter and year-to-date September results can be found in our earnings release.
Let me begin with our full year outlook. As announced this morning, we are reaffirming our 2016 reported diluted EPS guidance at prevailing exchange rates to be in a range of $4.53 to $4.58. Our guidance includes $0.35 of unfavorable currency and continues to represent a growth rate, excluding currency, of approximately 10.5% to 11.5% compared to our adjusted diluted EPS of $4.42 in 2015.
As a reminder, in the fourth quarter, we anticipate strong, currency-neutral net revenue growth, driven primarily by the annualization of price increases and the growth of RRPs. We also anticipate a favorable cost comparison, driven by the significant investments that we made in the fourth quarter of 2015 behind iQOS and our cigarette brand portfolio, including those related to the implementation of the EU Tobacco Products Directive.
Moving to our third quarter results. Net revenues and adjusted OCI increased by 3.6% and 4.3%, respectively, excluding currency, reflecting favorable pricing, partly offset by negative volume/mix, particularly in the EEMA region. Adjusted diluted EPS increased by 4%, excluding currency.
Our favorable pricing variance of $440 million in the third quarter was driven by positive contributions from all regions, notably EEMA. During the quarter, we announced or implemented price increases in a number of markets, including those shown on the slide, which should further support favorable pricing in the fourth quarter.
We recorded currency-neutral financial growth in the third quarter despite an organic cigarette shipment volume decline of 5.4%. The decrease was due mainly to lower cigarette industry volume in Argentina, Indonesia, the Philippines and Russia as well as lower cigarette market share, notably in North Africa, the Philippines and Russia, partly offset by market share growth in the EU region.
Year-to-date September, our cigarette shipment volume declined by 3.9%, consistent with the year-to-date August decrease that I referenced at Investor Day. We continue to anticipate a similar decline for the full year 2016.
Our shipment volume for heated tobacco sticks reached 2.1 billion units in the third quarter, an increase of approximately 900 million units compared to the second quarter of this year. While principally driven by Japan, all iQOS-launched markets contributed to this growth. While our cigarette market share, excluding China and the U.S., declined by 0.6 points in the third quarter due notably to North Africa, the Philippines and Russia, Marlboro cigarette share increased by 0.3 points, driven by the EU and Asia region.
Let me now move to select geographies, beginning with the EU region. Regional cigarette industry volume declined by 1.4% in the third quarter, contributing to a year-to-date September decrease of 0.2%. For the full year, we continue to expect a decline of around 1%. Our regional cigarette share in the quarter increased by 0.4 points, driven by the continued strong performance of Marlboro, which grew share in 4 of the region's top 6 markets by cigarette industry volume, notably Germany and Spain.
In Indonesia, we recorded sequential market share growth in the third quarter, driven by our strong performance in the full-flavor, machine-made kretek segment, notably following the geographical expansion of U Bold in June. To further enhance our position, in September, we launched Marlboro Filter Black kretek in 25 cities. Although it is early, we strongly believe that this offer will set the standard for the full-flavor, machine-made kretek segment.
In addition, this month, the Indonesian Ministry of Finance issued its 2017 excise tax regulation, which will result in a weighted average excise tax increase of approximately 10% industry-wide. As you may recall, the weighted average increase in 2016 was approximately 15%.
In Japan, our cigarette market share continued to stabilize and was essentially flat compared to the third quarter of last year. This performance is notable, given the impact of HeatSticks cannibalizations on our cigarette share and was supported by recent Lark and Marlboro launches.
iQOS continues to perform exceptionally well, with HeatSticks market share reaching 4.3% in the last week of September. In the third quarter, HeatSticks market share was 3.5%, an increase of 1.3 points compared to the second quarter of 2016. Importantly, the share gains have been achieved despite the limits we have placed on iQOS device sales since June.
PMI's total combined market share, including cigarettes and HeatSticks, was 27.9% in the third quarter, reflecting an increase of 2.5 points compared to the same period in 2015.
In North Africa, our third quarter market share was 24.6%, representing a sequential increase versus the second quarter. This growth was driven by the improving performance of Marlboro in Algeria, highlighting the early success of the initiatives that we shared during the Investor Day.
In Russia, the Ministry of Finance submitted a proposal earlier this month to raise the specific and the minimum excise tax levels for 2017 by approximately 10% above what is currently in the tax code. If the proposal is approved by the Duma and signed into law by the President, it will result, assuming full pass-on, in a total tax pass-on of approximately RUB 11 per pack in 2017. The ad valorem rate of 13% remains unchanged in the proposal.
I will finish my discussion of important developments with an update on the cigarette market in Argentina. While cigarette industry volume continues to be impacted by the significant excise tax-driven price increases in May, declining 14.1% in the third quarter, adult smokers appear to be adjusting relatively quickly to the higher retail prices, given the broader inflationary environment. The average monthly decline in August and September was 8%. We continue to expect a full year cigarette industry volume decline of around 12% in 2016 and a return to its low single-digit historical decline rate during 2017 once the May 2016 target increase has been lapped.
In conclusion, our third quarter results were in line with our expectations, and our full year outlook remains strong.
Thank you, and I will be happy now to answer your questions.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016

componenttext: Could you just talk about Russia for a minute? You -- we've seen the consumer there be pretty resilient in the past. You're now calling out some share pressure from pricing ahead of competitors. Are you seeing a change in the consumer approach? And are they -- is there any change in their willingness to spend? And especially, if so, could you give any sort of estimate of what you think the impact of the proposed tax increase might be as well?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I start with the last part. I mean, the impact, as I said, is about RUB 11 if passed on. So it's around the same level as we had last year. Despite the...
componenttext: I start with the last part. I mean, the impact, as I said, is about RUB 11 if passed on. So it's around the same level as we had last year. Despite the...

componenttext: Sorry. Could I clarify? I guess, I meant, with that increase, do you expect any different category impact this year versus last year -- next year versus this year?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: No, not really. I guess this is sort of the same increase as we had last year. And there was this 1 percentage point change in ad valorem, but I don't think it's going to change the dynamics between the segments. What you see in Russia on the consumer lev
componenttext: No, not really. I guess this is sort of the same increase as we had last year. And there was this 1 percentage point change in ad valorem, but I don't think it's going to change the dynamics between the segments. What you see in Russia on the consumer level is, yes, I mean, the consumer is looking value -- is looking for value. No question about it. I mean, at the Premium segment, at least judged by the share of Marlboro and especially Parliament, I mean, that will hold pretty strong pretty well. There is a down-trading. We observe a down-trading in the market but more between the mid- and the value segments. So this is where the extra price promotions or delays in the price implementations are most frequent. We're also launching our own initiatives in these segments. So I guess, also the share pressure which we have in Russia this year, I think we should start being on a positive share territory in 2017.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then with respect to Japan, I know it's maybe too early for you even to know, but do you have a sense with the proposed indoor smoking ban, if that might apply to iQOS as well?
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then with respect to Japan, I know it's maybe too early for you even to know, but do you have a sense with the proposed indoor smoking ban, if that might apply to iQOS as well?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Not at this level of detail, so we're not going into discussions. Well, I can say that we have a number of places in Japan where the existing smoking bans have been lifted due to the fact that iQOS is not a combustible product. Therefore, there is no burn
componenttext: Not at this level of detail, so we're not going into discussions. Well, I can say that we have a number of places in Japan where the existing smoking bans have been lifted due to the fact that iQOS is not a combustible product. Therefore, there is no burning, there is no smoke. So we'll have to see how it's going to evolve. But in a current environment with the restrictions for smoking, et cetera, as you notice, I mean, iQOS continues to gain the penetrations and the market share. So I don't think it's going to stall the growth prospects of iQOS in Japan.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Bonnie Herzog with Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Bonnie Herzog with Wells Fargo.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: My first question has to do with your volume. And I was just hoping you could drill down a little further on the declines in the quarter. And then what gives you the confidence that you're going to still be able to hit the down around 3.9% for the full ye
componenttext: My first question has to do with your volume. And I was just hoping you could drill down a little further on the declines in the quarter. And then what gives you the confidence that you're going to still be able to hit the down around 3.9% for the full year? And then curious to hear how that compares with your expectations for the industry volume for the full year.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wouldn't change -- we wouldn't change the expectations for the industry volumes, which we have shared during the Investors Day. I think that trends are pretty much null at this stage. I think there are some improvements will continue into 2017. Specific
componenttext: I wouldn't change -- we wouldn't change the expectations for the industry volumes, which we have shared during the Investors Day. I think that trends are pretty much null at this stage. I think there are some improvements will continue into 2017. Specifically, to us, I think -- I start maybe with the Latin America and Argentina. I think the consumer is adjusting to the prices pretty fast relative, obviously, to the price increase. I think this high inflation environment somehow helps. So I think, sequentially, we should see some -- less of the pressure from the volumes coming from -- or declines coming from Argentina. Algeria, which created quite a pressure on our volumes, and Marlboro -- including Marlboro this year, I mean, we start seeing the first signs of a recovery. It's going to take a while, but at least on the trend line, we crossed the lowest point. So I think already in Q4 and going into 2017, I think the pressure from Algeria, North Africa should ease. Indonesia, I think the tax proposal which came from the Ministry of Finance is manageable. I mean, you're looking for the just tax pass-on of about, say, 10% versus the 15% increase, which was -- which took place this year. So I think that should be helpful. In addition to the fact that I think -- at least judging for the last few quarters' performance of our share there, I think we should have less, if at all, share losses in 2017 than this year and, hopefully, a bit of stronger market than we have had in Indonesia this year. Philippines is a completely different story because it's all questions, how much we manage our mix to the positive territory. And so far, we are very successful with up-trading the markets to Marlboro, which continues to grow, and it's a very strong growth. And actually, we would like to enjoy this momentum for a longer while even if there are some pressures on the total industry volumes coming from the lower parts of the market. I think we would be fine with this. Pakistan, which also put quite a dent on our volume this year, that's presumably the most difficult to predict sort of the market because the other forces, which obviously play a role there. I mean, the contraband, I think, recently had reached about 1/3 of the market. So the question is where is the level of separation? And that said, so we can expect the worse than this. But again, from a financial perspective, it doesn't have that much of the impact -- doesn't have that much of a financial impact. So -- and Russia, the tax increase is also pretty manageable on the high side but comparable like we had at this year. And as I said earlier, I think Russia should also turn the corner when it comes to share decline. So next year, I guess, on a similar sort of the market dynamics, we should have less of a volume leakage due to the negative share performance.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That was really helpful. I appreciate that. And then I do have another question, I guess, on your other brand volume, which was down considerably in the quarter. So I was hoping you could talk a little bit about your strategy with some of these bran
componenttext: Okay. That was really helpful. I appreciate that. And then I do have another question, I guess, on your other brand volume, which was down considerably in the quarter. So I was hoping you could talk a little bit about your strategy with some of these brands. You touched on how the greater -- remember, at the Investor Day, you touched on having a greater focus on a fewer number of brands going forward. So I guess I'm assuming this is consistent with the sharper declines we've been seeing for some of the smaller brands. And I guess I was also hoping you could confirm that. Although these brands are declining rapidly, they're contributing nicely to margins as they're likely promoted less.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, these brands will, in most case, actually have pretty low margins. I mean, the 2 big brands, which are in other categories, will be Fortune and very much Jackpot in Philippines. So these are the brands which have a near 0 sort of the margin territory
componenttext: Yes, these brands will, in most case, actually have pretty low margins. I mean, the 2 big brands, which are in other categories, will be Fortune and very much Jackpot in Philippines. So these are the brands which have a near 0 sort of the margin territory, and a lot of consumers are going from these brands to Marlboro. So we actually, for the positive mix, are improving pretty fast our financial situation there, our financial results there. We will have also brands in Indonesia in this other category, which are not necessarily on the higher end of the margin spectrum. So I would rather say brand like a Jackpot in Philippines would presumably trade, so we are actually treating this more tactically. Fortune is a little bit different. It's a brand which we do manage and we stay focused. But we do also recognize that at least at this stage, Marlboro, due to the closure of the price gap, is a more attractive proposition for the consumer, and we're absolutely fine with that. And Indonesia, I mean, many of these local brands, the brands which we do support, but we also try to focus on what is dilutive to our margins.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then maybe my final question, Jacek. You guys definitely watched through iQOS a lot at your Investor Day, but could you possibly highlight a few possible updates in the last few months on the improvements you've seen with conversion and maybe ca
componenttext: Okay. And then maybe my final question, Jacek. You guys definitely watched through iQOS a lot at your Investor Day, but could you possibly highlight a few possible updates in the last few months on the improvements you've seen with conversion and maybe cannibalization rates?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Conversion, I don't think I have a fresher number than that we have shared at the Investor Day. I mean, there may be a few numbers which I still remember because some of these KPIs we're tracking even more frequently. I think at Tokyo, if you might rememb
componenttext: Conversion, I don't think I have a fresher number than that we have shared at the Investor Day. I mean, there may be a few numbers which I still remember because some of these KPIs we're tracking even more frequently. I think at Tokyo, if you might remember, the Tokyo market share, offtake share, at the Investor Day, which we shared, was 7%. We now stand at 7.3%. So we continue the growth, and the same is for Japan. I think our national offtake share the last week of -- or third week of September, which we have shared in Investors Day, 5.2%, now turns to be 5.5%. Then you consider pretty rapid share advancements, you're talking 20, 30 basis points in a span of a couple of few weeks. I have the same in Italy when I think the share in Italy, the launch area was 60 basis points, 0.6%, and now I think we lifted this last week of -- sorry, third week of October, I think the rating would be 0.8%. Switzerland, we lifted from 0.4% to 0.5%. The penetration rate, the number of devices sold continues to grow. So I think in all geographies, just from the top of my head, I mean, there is a continuous growth momentum, very much in line of what we have shared with the investors at Investors Day.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of James Bushnell with Exane.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of James Bushnell with Exane.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I have 2 questions, please. The first one is on iQOS in Japan. Clearly, you've limited the expansion because of the supply constraints you have. I just wondered if you could give us an estimate of what proportion of consumers don't have access to the prod
componenttext: I have 2 questions, please. The first one is on iQOS in Japan. Clearly, you've limited the expansion because of the supply constraints you have. I just wondered if you could give us an estimate of what proportion of consumers don't have access to the product right now and whether the existing users' over-index to smokers of a particular strength or taste of cigarettes. That's my first question.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: We see the less and less of the other proportional representation of former Marlboro smokers compared to the underlying share of Marlboro. So clearly, the iQOS is taking more a significant inroads into the competitive combustible portfolio. Now how much,
componenttext: We see the less and less of the other proportional representation of former Marlboro smokers compared to the underlying share of Marlboro. So clearly, the iQOS is taking more a significant inroads into the competitive combustible portfolio. Now how much, really, we have less unhappy consumers in Japan at this stage. I know that there are waiting lists. I know that the consumers have to enroll by name on this list, but to be frank, I don't have a number at this stage. The number exists somewhere. But we clearly -- we see how much of that backlog is the like of unserved consumers will have the moment when we will leave the cap, which we estimate to happen somewhere in the end of the Q1 next year when we'll be very comfortable with the HeatSticks supplies. But my gut feeling is we're not talking about a 5% or 10% sort of unsatisfied demand. I think the number is much higher than that.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Great. And then my second question, more of a modeling one, which is that your associate and minority lines look to have moved quite a bit since Q2. I just wondered if the numbers we're looking at in Q3 we could consider as more normalized post some
componenttext: Okay. Great. And then my second question, more of a modeling one, which is that your associate and minority lines look to have moved quite a bit since Q2. I just wondered if the numbers we're looking at in Q3 we could consider as more normalized post some of the changes you've had in those areas.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think so. I mean, there might be some movement. I think Russia should be -- the Megapolis should be okay. I think maybe there's some movements in North Africa around some of the structures, which we have in Egypt. But I think we should be pretty much in
componenttext: I think so. I mean, there might be some movement. I think Russia should be -- the Megapolis should be okay. I think maybe there's some movements in North Africa around some of the structures, which we have in Egypt. But I think we should be pretty much in line of what we could expect there. There are some currency -- the currency movements might have an impact on this line. And as you know, we have some exposure in Egypt on the -- we have to take the dollar exposure in Egypt, and there are some limitations in availability on the dollars in a country. So we might have some distortions with these lines coming from North Africa, Egypt, as I mentioned.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Matthew Grainger with Morgan Stanley.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is actually Pam Kaufman on for Matt. I just wanted to ask on pricing. It improved sequentially to about 6.5% but needs to accelerate further to reach your benchmark of 6% for the full year and presumably reach the -- help bridge the gap to strong fou
componenttext: This is actually Pam Kaufman on for Matt. I just wanted to ask on pricing. It improved sequentially to about 6.5% but needs to accelerate further to reach your benchmark of 6% for the full year and presumably reach the -- help bridge the gap to strong fourth quarter earnings growth. Can you review where you've seen incremental pricing recently that would allow you to deliver on this target for the full year?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: We should have in the Q4 of this year the strongest pricing variance compared to all the quarters. I mean, we're looking in the -- well in the north of a $500 million pricing variance in the quarter. And actually, it might be even closer to $600 million.
componenttext: We should have in the Q4 of this year the strongest pricing variance compared to all the quarters. I mean, we're looking in the -- well in the north of a $500 million pricing variance in the quarter. And actually, it might be even closer to $600 million. We should have -- all in all, in the fourth quarter, we should expect above the 10% uplift on the revenue quarter-on-quarter, okay, on an ex-currency basis. So as I said, this -- the growth in the fourth quarter, on the one hand, will be coming from the favorable comp, which we have on the costs, while we still continue spending, obviously, more behind on iQOS, but it is more on the combustible part of spending compared to the Q4 last year. But we also are looking into -- we expect to have quite a significant uplift in the net revenue and correspondingly contributions to the bottom line.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: So my question is on, actually, the mix impact because in addition to pretty healthy pricing, it sounds like the third quarter also benefited from strong mix. So how much is this geographic mix impact? And then when you think about the impact on iQOS, eit
componenttext: So my question is on, actually, the mix impact because in addition to pretty healthy pricing, it sounds like the third quarter also benefited from strong mix. So how much is this geographic mix impact? And then when you think about the impact on iQOS, either on price/mix, is there a way to kind of quantify how that would have impacted either the price or mix?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: The rate -- I mean, EU is doing well. So obviously, due to the margin, geographical margin split, I mean, on a geographical basis, the mix is working in our favor. If you go into individual countries, the countries with the worst mix in the quarter were a
componenttext: The rate -- I mean, EU is doing well. So obviously, due to the margin, geographical margin split, I mean, on a geographical basis, the mix is working in our favor. If you go into individual countries, the countries with the worst mix in the quarter were actually Indonesia and, if I recall well, actually was U.K. But overall -- but that's it essential. When it comes to iQOS, yes, obviously, they already start adding the support to the revenue growth, and it's going to be even stronger in the Q4 of this year already. I guess when we close the year, we will start talking more about the financial impact of iQOS at least on the revenue -- at the revenue level, but there is already some volume impact. You know that we have a capacity of about 7 billion available this year. We sold a little less than 4 billion. So I think we've been very transparent with one can expect from the volumes of iQOS in the fourth quarter, and that's going to help lifting the revenue growth quite a bit.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. So if you think about it, I think iQOS added about 1% to your total volume. So the revenue impact would have been higher in the second quarter -- I'm so sorry, in the third quarter?
componenttext: Okay. So if you think about it, I think iQOS added about 1% to your total volume. So the revenue impact would have been higher in the second quarter -- I'm so sorry, in the third quarter?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the pricing is at the Marlboro level, as you remember. Plus remember, in the revenue line, we'll also have devices, right, because we're selling the devices as well. So you have an uplift from the volume at the Marlboro price in a given geography, p
componenttext: Well, the pricing is at the Marlboro level, as you remember. Plus remember, in the revenue line, we'll also have devices, right, because we're selling the devices as well. So you have an uplift from the volume at the Marlboro price in a given geography, plus, obviously, the taxes and also the price at which we have the volume -- at which we're selling the devices to consumers. So they both contribute to the revenue.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just in Japan, I mean, it seems like your obviously contribution from iQOS is still very strong, but your combustible share has also gotten better. So can you just walk through how sustainable that sort of scenario of actually seeing combus
componenttext: Okay. And then just in Japan, I mean, it seems like your obviously contribution from iQOS is still very strong, but your combustible share has also gotten better. So can you just walk through how sustainable that sort of scenario of actually seeing combustible improvement, plus the iQOS contribution? It sounds like maybe Japan, your volume would have been up high single digits, ex inventory, if you add the iQOS volume.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think if you will take the full year impact, I mean, iQOS, clearly, is already a significant contributor to the -- to our business there. And look, I have to actually thank you for raising these questions because I should say how proud we are that
componenttext: Yes. I think if you will take the full year impact, I mean, iQOS, clearly, is already a significant contributor to the -- to our business there. And look, I have to actually thank you for raising these questions because I should say how proud we are that in 1 year, we managed to sort out the share pressure on the conventional business in Japan despite the fact that part of that share we have to gain for the cannibalization to iQOS. And in addition, we're so successful with iQOS. So I think the market share -- the biggest dynamics now which you will have in a market, I guess, is the cannibalizations and the movement between a combustible category, including our own portfolio, and iQOS. But the share leakage which we have to other pay segments and new pay segments, I mean, it seems at this stage that we have very successfully addressed. So it's pretty, pretty remarkable result actually for our Japanese organization.

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then just finally, on currency. I know at the Investor Day, you talked about currency in '17 being less of a headwind versus '16. But just if we kind of pool spot rates at these levels, is there any kind of guidance you can give, a little bit mo
componenttext: Okay. And then just finally, on currency. I know at the Investor Day, you talked about currency in '17 being less of a headwind versus '16. But just if we kind of pool spot rates at these levels, is there any kind of guidance you can give, a little bit more specific guidance in '17, particularly around the yen, just given your hedge strategy?

headline: Philip Morris International, Inc., Q3 2016 Earnings Call, Oct 18, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I guess 2 questions, actually -- sorry, 2 facts, which would help maybe better predict the currency on your side of ocean on the rises of election, in fact, decision about the interest rates. So I am a little bit more remote from this one. I guess th
componenttext: Yes. I guess 2 questions, actually -- sorry, 2 facts, which would help maybe better predict the currency on your side of ocean on the rises of election, in fact, decision about the interest rates. So I am a little bit more remote from this one. I guess the number of currencies, if I look how currencies were playing against us this year -- and remember, we started the Q1 -- I guess we had like a $0.19. Q2, we were $0.08 on EPS. Q3, we're at $0.04. So clearly, we could see that the number of currencies have started to put a less pressure on us. Currency, which I singled out during the Investors Day, which many of us sometimes tend to forget, I mean, we have some exposures in North Africa, in particular, in Egypt. So the Egyptian pound is a little bit of the worry, and I don't know how they're going to relax the currency rules and how much it's going to translate into the devaluation. Other than that, ruble is prevailing pretty okay, euro, Japanese yen. Some that we hedge, we already hedged some positions in 2017. But the yen already started to contribute positively in the last few months, in the last quarter definitely. So we'll have to wait until February, post the elections, post the Fed decision. And presumably, these two biggest unknowns will be removed and we'll see how the market price the currencies at that time.
